reviewText:
The original Dead Island was an enjoyable experience despite it's numerous flaws. Riptide addresses a few of these failings but it's essentially more of the same. It starts badly with a clichéd corrupt corporate suit and a conspiracy; thankfully however it's not the plot that drives Dead Island but the exploration, loot and combat. For all its poor writing and characterisation the setting is still superbly realised, a sun-drenched tropical island with just enough variation in locales to keep it interesting. Combined with the great combat and looting and there's still a lot to recommend with Riptide.

Apart from fixing a few bugs and being more stable the most noticeable changes to the formula are the addition of new transport, a zombie horde mode which happens at key moments as the story progresses and a handful of new zombie threats.

Pros:
- Very fun to play
- Co-op
- Lot of weapons
- Ability to mod weapons (barbed wire on bat, electric shotgun, etc.)
- Very long story
- Big maps
- Lots of zombies
- Gore

Cons:
- Not an interesting story
- Other than the main characters, all other charcters have the same facial animation, just diffrent clothings and voices
- Grapnics aren't very good
- Vehicles have terrible physics

I believe both Dead Island and Riptide are best played solo. Playing co-op is a completely different beast. Played solo Riptide is a tense game, one of fear and always looking over your shoulder. Played with friends it turns it into more of a fun fair, who can chop up the zombies faster than the other players with no tension and no sense of fear. So to best experience Dead Island I would recommend you skip the co-op and delve into what is still the best open-world zombie game available.
voteText: 216 of 245 people (88%) found this review helpful 12 people found this review funny

reviewText:
Man, I do not understand all the negativity these games receive. They are fun and atmospheric. If you like shivers up and down your spine and going in there anyway these games are for you.

Riptide is smaller than the original and maybe a little more polished in the gameplay and pacing. The looting system is more relevant with shops and trading more accessible than in the original game. Buildings and tunnels are refreshingly brief compared to the first game.

Co-op is very smooth. If you join someone else's co-op game and become Player 2 and later on someone else joins as Player 3, when Player 1 subsequently goes home both you and Player 3 continue on together in your own game seamlessly and without hesitation. Smooth as you please.

Some reports on the web make great play on the idea that Riptide is an overwhelming grind of infinitely spawning Infected everywhere you go but I've been through the whole thing twice now and it's just not. There are two places I can think of where a group of three Infected will infinitely respawn after a very short delay and you just hurry past. Learn to hide. Very small deal.

The only negative point for me is the camera movement when you climb to the top of something, it waves about and can leave you queasy until you get your sea legs for it. This is an unfortunate barrier to entry unless you learn to just look away.

Having said that, many games leave me seasick when I pick them up again after a long break.

And for those who love their Achievements these are all quite doable.

reviewText:
Fixing all the flaws of the previous Dead island game, this one burst out of the gate with minimal issues. (7.1 surround sound can be staticy and need some adjusting, but that may have been resolved since release)

Coop is the best way to experience it, but you can have hours of fun solo as well.   Each class has their own unique play style and great dialogue.  Whether you're Sam B referencing your rap career (Or blasting your latest hit on a stereo) or the Steven Seagal in Under Siege rip off character just kicking zombies so hard they explode against walls, it's a blast.

It's over the top, it's silly, and it's great fun.

reviewText:
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=cFEZa-DsQhU

Riptide takes place immediately after the conclusion of the first game with its protagonists being detained abroad an Australian Defense Force ship by Colonel Hardy and Frank Serpo. The survivors of the first game meet a new playable character, John Morgan who is also immune to the infection. The ship wrecks on the shores of Palanai after being overrun and the survivors find themselves in a similar predicament to the one on Banoi.

Quests in Riptide are ripped strait from Ye Olde Grimoire of RPG quest design, that leans heavily on taking the longest possible route in getting from point A to point B. For example, a character wants you to rescue her from a flooded basement where a shorted out fuse box is electrifying the water. Of course the front door is locked so you have to kill half a dozen zombies so that you can find the an access point on the roof. Once there, you find the fuse box is locked and you have to kill the keyholder so that you can open the box. Most RPGs reserve this kind of design for optional tasks but it's a staple of the games main quests as well. Without any character development or world building side quests become real life chores when tackled alone. The only reprieve from this antiquated quest design comes from the new hold out missions. These quests emphasize Riptide's co-op gameplay by having your characters fortify and defend a position.

Deadzones are instanced areas that contain a boss or special infected. Riptide contains around two dozen of these areas and they have one of five layouts so it isn't long before these sequences come off as boring cut and paste filler content. The bosses themselves are just special infected that are given some sort of additional buff resulting in thugs that move as fast as infected and Butchers that regain heath after successful strikes. Speaking of special infected, several new types have been added. Screamers make a horrendous noise that prevents your character from attacking, wrestlers are large freaks with a club like arm and a tremendous amount of health and grenadiers are zombies in hazmat suits that throw toxic body parts at you. These new additions are welcome but with so many other zombie games you will come away with the sensation that you have fought these enemies elsewhere.

Melee combat has gone largely unaltered with the exception of an ability that allows you to drop on top of enemies if you are in an elevated position. Also the ability to level each weapon type has been added. Each level unlocks a perk such as additional experience or reduced stamina use. Outdoor environments in Riptide look pretty decent. The character models don't fare so well however. They appear waxy with poorly animated faces and cold dead eyes. Some of the textures on their clothing can also be woefully low res. The gore and viscera are appreciable though as the flesh of your foes can be burnt and hacked away, reacting to the type of weapon you use. Indoor instances suffer from really bland lighting that is devoid of softness or nuance.  It does little to enhance the atmosphere and since the game isn't very scary to being with relying on your flashlight and flares does little to create tension. Also some areas are missing textures. The soundtrack fares better though with a mix of synth and piano that evoke the soundtracks of Lucio Fulci's zombie flicks from the late 1970's and early 1980's. The music succeeds in conveying the desperation and futility of surviving that neither the narrative nor the gameplay are equipped to convey. Sound effects are solid and some of the roars and cries from the undead can be unnerving. As for the voice acting, well, lets just say it matched the cold, dead eyes of the NPC character models perfectly...

reviewText:
I really do like this game. Although some people choose to slag it off because it is literally a reskin. I personally believe this game is great. I put enough time into this game to reach level 50. There is alot of pros and many cons but this game is still great and really is a good edition to the zombie genre. The story is weak but gameplay is great and for that i will get straight to the point and list pros and cons.

Pros:
Great gameplay
Nice loot system
Decent crafting mechanic
Great Replayabillity (If i spelt that correct)
Awesome new weapons and mechanics which improve upon its last game

Cons
Blank story
Some plot holes
Plain and sometimes dumb AI

Final verdict:
Do buy this game. Its fun and simple to get used to. Dont let my cons put you off, The story really isn't bad but it does leave gaps. Enjoy!

reviewText: Following the success of the original Dead Island, and offering the ability to import your character from the First Dead Island, Riptide continues the story. Unfortunately without spoilers I can't not say any more; However,  I have to say, it was fun the first time I played it. You can play through multiple times as the different characters and it offers a slightly different experience, due to the individual characters perspective.  If it is on sale and you enjoy Zombie Survival games, it might be worth a shot for you. It does get somewhat repetitive, but the characters are interesting to a point so it is at least entertaining. I would recommend it, but strongly recommend playing the first Dead Island and importing your character if you can.

reviewText:
Riptide is an awesome sequel game. Despite the old engine the ingame picture looks fantastic (by release date ofc). Locations became much more bigger, devs added lots of new zombie types. There's new transport - boats. Driving them and smashing drowners at the same time is insane! One more thing to mention is that there's a load of quests... Man! 80. God. Damn. Quests. And also there's a new playable character appeared - John Morgan.
Riptide is mostly co-op focused, but if you don't have a partner it won't be lost, you won't be bored. The game is as good in singleplayer as in co-op, at least it'd be better to chose singleplayer neither co-op with a random partner.
In addition, when you just stalking this island it seems that it's alive, full of life (dead one anyway). It's not like most of open world games, here the world is not statical, everytime you do something it changes. When you complete the story, it will be still interesting to run around this island once more and more...
Of cons I can mention only small nuber of bugs and not very interesting plot, just like a typical zombie survival drama.

reviewText:
Dead Island Riptide takes place exactly where Dead Island left off.  In Dead Island 1 you leave a prison and that is where Dead Island Riptide begins.  The same cast of playable characters is included along with a new character named Logan, meaning if you want to hear all the fun quotes maybe play through the game 5 times.  The game can be as short or as long as you want it to be which makes it very fun and easy to play.  Animations and assets are all the same as the first game so if your computer can run that it should have no problem with Dead Island Riptide.  For those having trouble or if you want to change the FOV, turn off VAC, and see this forum thread for a helpful launcher that modifies the game, the person who made it did a great job so you dont need to be some technosuperhacker to figure out how to install it:  http://steamcommunity.com/app/216250/discussions/0/828937261940292800/

Modding the weapons is fun like making a skull on a stick shoot fire out of its eyes! Or guns that shoot poisonous bullets.  A fun zombie game with an ok world to get lost in, the swamp map which is the first one isnt too interesting but the city one which is second is fun to run around in.  This version has less bugs than the last game such as players can chat in this using a controller where in the original Dead Island they cant.

Rating:  7/10  Value:  $9.99

reviewText:
4/10

I love LOVE Dead Island. The modding, co-op, missions, world, cutting zombies to pieces or using a electrified hammer to explode their body into a wall. It was amazing and maybe one of my favorite zombie themed games.

But this one.. It has some improvements, but too many flaws. This could have been better than Dead Island, and maybe most co-op games.

Pro's:
The story is much better than the first game, the modded weapons are cool looking and you can use a ♥♥♥♥ing golf club as a weapon.. that is amazing. lol.

I love the new character John, I was wishing there was a hand to hand fighter in Dead Island, and now I have one. He has great abilities with claws, and a powerful kick to knock zombies far away to get some space. The character are well made, even feel like they have a bit more personality now.

If you use Xian, in the first game blunt weapons aren't too great for you. But now, you can level up 4 different skills with weapons.
(EXAMPLE: My John is skilled with guns, hand to hand and blades now. I just have more of a bonus with claws over the rest.)
This opens up your choices on how to make blood rain from above than before.

Guns. They are now actually useful!! Though ammo is rare, you can actually do real damage to zombies with guns if you do headshots, unlike the first game where they barely did anything unless you were purna(and even then, it wasn't all that much better.)

I actually saw in a cutscene when asked about being immune, John states that the rest are at the base, instead of having invisible ninja survivors with you that don't show up in the game, until a major cutscene.

All this is great, and so much of a improvement but here are why the score is so low.

Con's:

Lets start with the most basic complaint for people. The frame rate. I see people complain it is bad. Which I can agree.. Then you get people who say it runs fine for them. Great so because 1 out of 50 people says it works fine, means the game is fine. No.

Dead Island ran fine. But Riptide runs at half speed unless my resolution is 800/600 and windowed. Which I can deal with, games aren't about looks, its about the gameplay.

The game feels terrible unbalanced. Zombies kill you within a few hits, and if they throw a throwing weapon at you, there is a 90% chance its a 1 hit kill. (stabbed no, thrown yes.) and they rarely miss.

The new mutations look amazing, and very nice, but I have a complaint for 2 types.
The Screamer, she is faster than you, kills you quickly, her screams stuns you from attacking, and even if you are hitting her, she can scream. Her only weakness, is low health. So if you can get the drop on her quickly you can be ok..

second, the named zombies.. They can't be knocked down, slow down, they are basically like a butcher and thug combined. Very unbalanced and unfair, especially when they are surrounded by a army of walkers.

This game is riddled with bugs. Remember all the bugs in dead island? Well, double it. Did no one beta test it? I killed a army of zombies, then when I had to kill the boss" zombie
date: they all respawned behind me. I have lost thrown weapons

reviewText:
We're back again in beautiful sunny Panama where the water is clear blue, the vegetation is lush and green, the natives are zombies and the trailers play backward. The real question you need to ask yourself is how many zombies in your lifetime do you want to kill at close range. Take that number and keep multiplying it until you get bored and you have this experience. Dead Island Riptide is the continuation of the original Dead Island where the four survivors from the original game are thrown into the fire once again with a fifth playable character. For those who are unaware, Dead Island Riptide is no different than its predecessor, it is a single player and cooperative open world, first person melee combat game against the living dead and a few other mutants.

I'll start with the good, the graphics are beautiful from far away. You have gorgeous green vistas, crystal water and a sunny day, unless its raining. The setting is gorgeous, even if its a zombie action game set in broad daylight with no nighttime to be found outside of the first mission. Upon closer inspection the textures might not be as beautiful and the character models of the living can be worse than those of the dead.

The game plays well enough for any melee focused game. There's an attack or shoot button, an aim button for when you want to aim your gun or take aim with a weapon to throw it. You also have typical sprint, jump and squat buttons for traversing the area. Dead Island Riptide is a stamina game, so you need to pace your zombie beat downs. Run out of stamina and you'll be ineffective. Everything costs stamina except shooting guns.

Outside of running and walking, there are boats and jeeps to take you where you're headed. Its fun to just sit back, mow down some zombies or even let another player drive. The boat has a speed boost to ram zombies, otherwise they can pull someone off. You'll also find fast travel and there is a big map and a mini map so you can find the are you're looking for.

There's a rhythm to attacking enemies, hit them and wait for them to telegraph their attacks, then step back. Repeat, repeat, repeat. You will unlock abilities as you level your character that introduce game changing attacks such as uppercuts and running kicks. The unlocked attacks feel good. Kicking a zombie off a cliff or even into a wall feels brutal, effective and fun to watch. Zombies will both charge at you or shamble around. Others lay in wait pretending to be dead, especially floaters in the water.

Sure I say melee focused game, there are guns, pistols, assault rifles, nail and flare guns, but the ammunition costs money or its rare to come by. Its just easier to use your fists, knives and blunt objects. There are even a few throwable weapons to keep things interesting. Molotiv cocktails, grenades and the like. Throwing a bladed weapon feels satisfying when it severs an arm or lops a head off. The knives get stuck in your foes and you can pull it out of their bodies to attack them again. Zombies will get up in your grill, grab you and you need to push one button then press another before a timer expires to deck them back.

Your combat does feel fluid, your movements feel fluid for the most part. Other times you can feel drunk as your character bobs and weaves. Just because you've stopped means your character's body has to stop or even start for that matter. It takes a while to get used to it.

Everything is a former human. The zombies were people, the thug zombies were tall people, the ogres were crazy old men, the vomit spitting husky gents were people and the boil covered exploders were also people who are now mutated and discusting. You'll be killing your fellow human beings over and over again. That's not to guilt trip you, but that's just to say you're doing the same thing constantly. As I played it became an issue to constantly engage myself into fights. I'd avoid fights like you would in a real zombie apocalypse. Why fight an enemy when its just easy to avoid them? Wall of zombies? Jump kick through them. Fighting when you have to reduces the tedium.

With no field of view slider, you'll often have tunnel vision and you'll be unaware of the zombies sneaking up behind you as you're curb stomping a victim. I for one feel bad for the zombies. I feel like a mugger that's just beating down the welcome wagon and stealing their cash. Why am I stealing their cash? To purchase upgrades. Yes there are tool benches that you can repair, upgrade and craft new weapons. Why does an unmanned tool bench require money? Because its the honor system of course. The game never mentions it, but I just assume that's the case. I like to fill in the blanks with the story, because there are a lot of them.

The story continues where the last one left off. You're aboard a naval vessel in rough waters that just so happens to be invested with flesh eating zombies. Things quickly go wrong and the ship serves as a brief tutorial before you're dropped off on a different part of Panama that is stricken with the same plague. Your objective is to go mission after mission to get a boat to get out of the area before its bombed. Well that is the start of the plan, then from there, you can do what you want. All of the people you rescue, help and aide will perhaps die anyway in the bombing that might happen. I never stuck around for the end of the game, because like most open world games, you do it at your leisure, so if you never complete it, does it really get bombed?.

The game feels like an easy enough single player experience, but the game gets even easier with online multiplayer. You'll receive a notice that someone else is in the area and you can accompany them and complete the mission together and go from there. I think it adds a lot of life to the game, although some people are completely clueless and its shocking how they got so far. Another thing that I took note of is everyone's microphone is on always. I've overheard completely other conversations from people that are oblivious their microphone hears everything with no filter. Riptide does streamline things, you can have one player go to the objectives and the others can warp to that person instantly.

There are five characters and they all play the same, but come with different abilities. Things like Logan can retrieve all thrown weapons. Xian lets you backstab for more damage. Sam B can ram and tackle enemies, rather than the football playing Logan. John is a master of unarmed combat and learns weapons quicker, and Purna can heal herself and the group. Each of the five is better with different forms of combat. Everything from unarmed combat to blunt weapons. Each of these can be leveled up over time.

You'll find little bugs and glitches here and there, but nothing game breaking. Characters will talk without moving their mouth. The animations can be laughably lifeless. You can kick a zombie into a ragdoll and watch as their arm gets caught in mid air and they're pulled up. All of these things are forgivable and enhance the game. There are horde mode missions where you first need to fortify a fortress and then survive an onslaught of zombies.

The think that hinders the game is just how much of it is tedium. Go here, get this and bring it back. When you're here, there are zombies, when you're there, you'll find zombies and when you come back, you'll find leprechauns, but no there are just zombies. There's also no true death in Riptide. Every death respawns you with less cash ensuring that you will always persevere as long as you put more time in.

The original Dead Island is the game with all of the fame, while Riptide was just squeezed out with little fanfare. The hype was gone and dead from the original and its more an issue that people can only stand so much melee combat before they want more. Riptide is still a good game, its just tough to recommend with its repetition and lack of variety.

reviewText:
It starts promisingly enough: a mad dash off a sinking ship, a military coup, and a zombie horde just aching to be shown the business end of a shotgun. And then, just like that, the promise is taken away. Dead Island: Riptide teases far more in its opening minutes than it ever manages to deliver across its lengthy campaign. There's no drama, and little excitement. Instead, there's a rehash of old ideas, combat that's fun for all of five minutes, and a seemingly never-ending slog of repetitive missions filled with characters that have the emotional depth of a wet sponge. If there were ever a video game equivalent of smacking your head against a brick wall, Riptide would be it.

The story--and that's using the word generously--is filled with the sort of terrible dialogue, hammy voice acting, and cliches you'd expect to see in an awful zombie spoof, or at best, a trashy B movie. But there's no sense of humour or self-awareness here: to Riptide's detriment, it takes itself very seriously. And that seriousness is hard to swallow when you have to look after a bunch of shallow, argumentative characters who utter irritating swears every few minutes and prove so unlikable that you're willing them to be torn apart by the zombie horde, just so you can have some peace and quiet. Then there's the plot itself, which endlessly meanders between government conspiracy, sci-fi, and human interest, without even the slightest sense of direction.

This all makes it so very hard to care about anything that happens in Riptide. By the time you drag yourself through to the disappointing ending, apathy has taken over to the point where you wouldn't bat an eyelid at even the most grand of revelations. And that's only if you can muster up enough energy to make it that far. Riptide's sandbox island of Hanoi isn't filled with the fun zombie-killing adventures you might expect. Instead, there are fetch quests: lots of fetch quests. And within those fetch quests are yet more fetch quests.

Nearly every single one of the main missions and side quests requires you to head over to a part of the island, find an item, and bring it back to base. Often, before you can retrieve said item, the game makes you fetch something for the person who holds the item, thus creating a fetch quest within a fetch quest. What's more, the narrative reasoning behind each quest is questionable. Why some stranded villager might be after a few measly bucks when the entire island has been overrun with flesh-eating zombies that threaten the very existence of humankind is puzzling.

To make matters worse, the combat that ties the whole thing together remains largely unchanged from that of Dead Island, which is to say it's massively frustrating. The focus is on melee weapons, ranging from blunt objects like baseball bats and shovels, through to blades like carving knives and sickles. Most can be upgraded using items scavenged from around the island, with hidden blueprints giving you access to wilder designs. And initially at least, bludgeoning a zombie to death with an improvised, nail-covered baseball bat is amusing, thanks to the resulting blood splatters, severed limbs, and grisly sound effects.

The limitations of the combat soon become clear, though. Attacking zombies still feels wildly inaccurate, slow, and very dull, making it difficult to truly master. The result is that the combat quickly deteriorates into a repetitive mess as you kick a zombie backward, flail randomly at it, back off while it attacks, and then repeat the whole process ad nauseam. A stamina bar ensures you can't just spam an attack--particularly when you're using heavier weapons that drain the bar faster--but rather than giving the game a more realistic feel, it just further enhances the dull combat.

The vast majority of the zombies you face attack in the same way, rushing towards you until you knock them back with a kick to start the dull attack process. There are some special zombies that remain unchanged from those in Dead Island, including charger, spitter, and boomer types; they have slightly different movesets here, but you end up tackling them in exactly the same way, because your options are so limited. For a game so focused on combat, it's galling that you spend most of your time wanting to avoid zombies, just so you can spare yourself the resulting tedium.

Using a vehicle to get around takes some of the edge off of that tedium, because ploughing through groups of zombies in a jeep or cutting through them in a rickety old boat is far quicker than melee. Inevitably, though, you're still forced to engage in hand-to-hand combat once you reach your destination. Guns do arrive much later, but the weedy, inaccurate shooting isn't something to look forward to. Neither are Riptide's few horde missions, where you must protect your base from an onslaught of evil zombies. You can put up fences, lay mines, and take on a few side quests (of the fetch variety, naturally) in order to strengthen your defences, but it's all moot: just repeat your trusty kick

Okay, so, after finnishing this game my final expressions were.... WOW
I was never Dead Island fan, it changed when I got my hands on Dead Island: Epidemic, but thats different story.
Simply, this game caught me, and it does not want to let me go! I did not even finish original DI..cmon Riptide... but I fell in love with this game.
What do I think:
The story is catchy, pretty catchy. (I dont understand why everybody says it is not, I found original DI story boring, not this one) Lot of plot twists, thats what I like. And a new character, maybe that is the reason why I tryied this game, because John Morgan is someone I deeply sympathize with.
Gameplay is pretty much the same, game has same mechanics as the original one, but now, you can have a boat! Ima on a boat..yeeaaah. Deal with it XD
+ Still the same awesome co-op mode
Game also showed us 3 new big mosters, Floater, Screamer and Wrestler. Also zombies behave more aggresive way than before. Zombieeess.... XD
Bugs? Yep, I found some. This game taught me one thing: never try to raft a boat between rock and a tree, never again.
Also, in some quest, zombies you need to kill sometimes vanish through closed doors you cant open and get literally stuck" nowhere and you cant reach them.

reviewText:
Okay, so don't get me wrong. Despite all the bugs and annoyances, I LOVED the original Dead Island. I was overjoyed when Dead Island: Riptide was coming out, and instantly smacked down my preorder. I launched the game as soon as I could, comforted at the familiar feel of the game. The controls instantly flowed back to me, the gameplay style..... and all the bugs, glitches, and frustration with the original Dead Island

Pros:
+ Interesting new story
+ Style of gameplay very similar to first, fluid for experienced players
+ Importing of characters from the original supported
+ New character!
+ New skill tree!

Cons:
- Next to none of the glitches from the first were patched for this
- Zombie AI isn't that much better
- Storyline was far too short
- Not only not optimized for PC, some actions still show Xbox controls, such as the RS stick to break a door handle
- Bigger focus on guns" claim was not true (I only call this negative because it was a false claim). The Nail Gun
recommended: but that's one gun. Not really a 'bigger focus on guns'."

reviewText:
An addictive game to play, not so repetitive, and your average time killer-game at best(seriously you wouldn't know how much time have been passed while playing this game, especially with a partner or two), you just want to keep playing and playing again, Missions? there are dozen of them from Primary to Side Missions, as for the side missions they wouldn't come at your face right away, instead you need to find the quest givers and whatnot and those Missions are very rewarding.

The Storyline is somewhat great, at least it is still corresponding with Dead island's story(after the incident in Banoi), Weapon Modification is the strong element in Dead Island franchise(I guess) and it's lil' bit improved from the previous game, Combat Sytem has been refined, New Weapons, and a honorable mention of New Feature such as Horde Defense which this game really needs; Horde Defense is awesome for those who never feels enough kickin' zombie's asses for they will keep coming to you waiting their head to be decapitated, make this game worth every buck.

Despite the lack of attention from the developers to fix the annoying Bugs/Glitches that could happen at anytime like distorting sound, or even no sound at all at some point in game and sort of, I however couldn't careless about it because the fun from this game covers the annoyment I get from the aforementioned Bugs/Glitches.

reviewText:
A big hells yeah for a recommendation for this game.

Dead Island: Riptide returns for more zombie killing action. Gorgeous visuals plus continuous missions make this game really addicting.

An inifnite array of mods allows for some wicked weapon customization. Where else will you find a mod for an electric speargun or a poison auto rifle?

What  I love about this game is that it continues the missions from one locale to the next, much like the first Dead Island.

Looking forward to Dead Island 2 when it comes out.

Definite money for your value here.

reviewText:
Terrible, terrible console port.

They managed to program this game so poorly that the very act of using a keyboard and mouse causes a massive microstudder issue. This issue is so widespread the deveopers have made a user mod a sticky on the forums, yet they refuse to fix the underlying issue causing this.

Even V-Sync was somehow broken in the porting process, enabling it causes the game to lock at 30 FPS (console frame rates), meaning if you do not wish to see tearing, or like me this game runs at such a crazy high FPS it actually causes your GPU to overheat. You must enable system wide V-sync using your video card manufacturer's software.

To top off the port-istis this game suffers from, anti aliasing is not an option. Thats right! a game released in 2013 that's not a flash game somehow does not have any option for anti aliasing, not just one type, NONE, zero, zilch, nada. This is unacceptable and I for one will go out of my way to never puchase another Deep Silver game, as their track record for PC releases is as terrible as this game.

reviewText: This is pretty much the exact same thing as Dead Island. The only thing they changed was the combat system and all they did was add levels for specific weapons and new weapons. The story sucks and is drawn out.The voice acting sucks. All the quests are pretty much get me x and ill give you y". I'm pretty sure there's less quests in this game than the first. One thing that annoys me is how in the first game there's multiple groups of people in different places
date: so there are more side quests. In this one you just move from place to place with your group
recommended:
so there's pretty much no side quests. The environment sucks in this game. The city is awful compared to the first one. Unless there's a story quest you don't run into bandits. The jungle is flooded with little boats so you have to walk extremely slow in the water. The game feels rushed consisting of a lot of bugs. They could have added so much to make the game good but they just made Dead Island 1.5.


Why you should wait for a massive price cut or avoid altogether:

1. If you were severely disappointed by the first one and told yourself you'd only buy a sequel if they made improvements because the ones made (fire weapons actually give light in this game) are minimal and not a enough to warrant a purchase.

2. Glitches abound

3. The story defeats itself on many levels (it's also boring and confusing)

4. There is zero improvement on the combat mechanics

5. Zombies respawn even after rooms and spaces have been cleared

6. You were hoping for more "survival horror" elements; they were nearly completely removed from this game"

reviewText:
This game is pretty much just like the first game. Sure I loved the first Dead Island, but Riptide doesn't improve anything that needed improving. And to me seems worse.

With some minor improvements such as alcohol, molotov's grenades no longer taking up inventory space and there are now specific weapons classed as throwing which also don't waste inventory space, such as throwing knives.

I like that I could import my lvl 52 character.

Story was not as good as the first and neither were the locations,  weren't as interesting or as fun to explore. Walking slowly through flooded jungle becomes tiresome. It feels more like a tunnel than open world.

Dislike that still guns can only be found in later lvls,  nor can you store excess ammo in your inventory, can only have maximum in your gun and that's it.

For completing a mission my lvl 70 character is awarded a purple lvl 15 pistol. Rewards should be equivalent to my characters lvl.

I carried a fuel container to a petrol bowser and left it there and went into the nearby bungalow which loaded as a seperate zone and fought some killer zombie and came out and my fuel container was not there anymore, it was listed as back where I picked it up from. Really annoying that when you go into bungalows and caves they load as a seperate area and when you go back out everything is reset including zombies, cars and items.
This is really annoying, that I have to trek all that way again.

Also going into another zone such as a building and out again will cause the side quest you were tracking to change to tracking the main quest instead.

Ordinary Walker Zombie's can one hit kill very accurately by throwing a weapon at you. A bit ridiculous and contradictory considering they aren't smart enough to climb a ladder, but are smart enough to use and throw a knife at you. Zombies are meant to be mindless and it takes a being with a mind and reason to be able to use a weapon. (I know zombies could throw weapons in the first game, but that didn't result in 1 hit kills with full health).

Respawns are way too fast.

I clear an area and zombies respawn moments later. They seem to make respawns in Riptide way too fast. I liked how it was In the first game, the area would stay clear for quite a long while.

Still no autosave added, not being able to save when you want is a pain, the game only saves when you quit or reach cheackpoints. I exited the game after the survivors moved from Paradise camp to Halai Village, but when I reloaded my game I was not in Halai village which is SE, for some stupid reason my character was all the way fartherest south west point in Pearl Sands. It should leave your character where you quit. Not on the total opposite side of where your character last was. Quitting and reloading  has the problem of not knowing where your character will be as it's often not where you last were.

There's too many annoying things that make Riptide not as fun as the first.
The game was sort of fun, but also frustrated me alot and took patience to be able to endure the frustrating elements, it felt like a backward step with this game instead of forward.

I'd rate it 6/10

reviewText: Fixed bugs from the first part, but is there anything else?The biggest sin of Dead Island: Riptide is 90% identity with the original. Even if some gameplay elements were added and they made changes for the better in some important cases it would be difficult to speak about evolution. Yes, due to these changes I definitely had more fun than in the first part but piercing feeling of experiencing deja vu didn't leave me almost to the end. Riptide is playable, it can give quite a lot of fun. However, this is clearly the production aimed at people who are fans of the original Dead Island and they simply want to have more of the same. The others have a big chance to confuse these two games. You know what? It's shame that Dead Island: Riptide wasn't the first one. And only one.

reviewText:
If you liked Dead Island, you will love Riptide too; however at sale price.

Not much has changed, but good news is that this game improved SOME of the problems Dead Island had. It's much better experience now. Much smoother too. Story for me personally was not that great. Locations were promising at first, but later on it turned out to be copy/paste of some of them from the first game.

Riptide will allow you to import save from your first game and continue with talents from that point. However all your weapons will be gone. Best weapons will come either from quests or metal chests found in game - though that's so rare that I found only one in whole playthrough. Upgrading is a must as well as making some mods if you want most damage.

Quest wise, this game is not as good as first one in my opinion. Often you will be asked to bring some stuff to NPC or save location from rushing horde of zombies.

For an Expansion, 10 hour span of almost complete quests is not that bad I guess, but not at full price. After all this is just an expansion with not much new stuff, but rather prolonged story of original Dead Island.  Though completion of the game was only 50% mind you, so if you are looking for perfect run it will take more time.

Co-Op was completely fine. We finished game duo. It's fun if you can find fun in anything besides main features of the game. Otherwise it's straight forward - slash zombies, turn in, slash more zombies, jump on them, kick them, hit them with a car, with motorboat, with ... you get the point ...
When it comes to joining others, game does good job at that too, even with bizare level differences.

Sadly once you decide to finish main story you can't go back to finish all quests. Game is fair and asks you do you want to finish story however. If you do decide to do so, you will have to play all over again with current character progress.

Finally, just like I wrote in first sentance - if you liked original Dead Island you will love this expansion too. If you didn't like Dead Island you wont find anything different in Riptide.

Cons:
Not a whole lot different than the first game. Mainly a new setting. No real new mechanics.
Short-ish (could have ended it around 12 hours in)
Mini map compass is janky and often unreliable
Going to a new location often resets your current quest to the main one, forcing you to update what quest you are on.

All in all, it was more of the same. But I liked the first game (despite being rough - as this one is too).  It has been a few years since I played the first one, so it felt familiar, but not too much so.

reviewText:
Dead Island: Riptide is essentially a very large expansion pack for Dead Island: it has a new playable character, some new weapons and enemies, a couple of new gameplay elements, and some enhancements and refinements to the core gameplay. These additions do very little to change the Dead Island experience: if you didn't like Dead Island before, Riptide won't make you a fan. If you did enjoy Dead Island though, Riptide is more of the same but a little bit better.

After a brief prologue on a doomed naval ship, Riptide dumps players on another tropical island of the undead and tasks them with escaping. To do this, many fetch quests will have to be undertaken and many more zombies will have to be slain in the most violent ways possible. Fetching and killing grants experience points (XP), which is used to upgrade your character's skills. Anyone who played Dead Island with be right at home with Riptide.

Like in Dead Island, Riptide focuses fairly heavily on melee combat and it still looks and sounds brutal, with limbs, heads, and blood flying all over the place. Weapons can be upgraded to inflict various types of damage (bleeding, fire, poison, etc.) and zapping and frying zombies and watching them twitch and scream is morbidly satisfying.

Guns and ammo are much more plentiful this time around and firearms are a bit more satisfying to shoot when compared to the first game. An increase in the amount of workbenches and merchants also means you're never too far from a freshly-upgraded and repaired weapon.

Riptide's two new main gameplay elements are boats and siege missions. Motor boats are needed to traverse the flooded areas of the island; they're much like the driveable trucks, only now the floaty handling is intentional. Zombies can be run over with the boats, and sometimes they'll pull themselves onto the watercraft and drag you overboard unless you beat them at a life-or-death minigame. Boats are featured heavily in the first half of the game, but once you make it to the island's main town you'll never use one again.

Siege missions in Riptide are much like the zombie modes in other popular games. In these, you have to barricade your location and fend off zombies for a pre-determined amount of time. Siege missions are fun for a bit, but they drag on way too long and become boring after a while. Luckily, there aren't very many of them.

The one other new thing in Riptide worth mentioning is the new playable character. He's essentially Wolverine from X-Men and can unleash powerful punches and kicks. This guy is fun to play around with, but if you don't want to use him you can play as one of the returning characters or import your levelled-up character from the original game.

Riptide's new enemies are passable but nothing to get excited about. You can rest assured that they're completely original creations and weren't ripped off from Left 4 Dead, though. The returning zombies are identical to their Dead Island counterparts, as they don't seem to have any new animations or sound effects. They are basically pallette-swaps, with different colored clothes.

This recycling theme runs throughout Riptide: it's painfully obvious to anyone who played Dead Island that many character models, voice clips, art assets, sound effects, and animations in Riptide were taken straight from the original game byte-for-byte and not changed. Riptide borrows from itself too, with lots of copy-and-pasted rooms. One location even features multiple whiteboards with the exact same hand-written message on each. To make matters worse, some of these whiteboards are positioned right next to each other. That's just lazy.

Riptide really *is* more of the same. Often literally.

Despite these issues, Riptide is still fun. The environment is atmospheric, and lots of time can be spent exploring it. Zombie-killing is still visceral (just as long as you're using a controller), and building the best character to effectively kill the undead will take some work and experimentation. Sound effects are great (not surprising, since 90% off the audio effects were taken from Dead Island), and the awful voice-acting and dialog are good for some unintentional laughs. The story is zombie-movie cliche (What's that you say? The zombie outbreak is the result of a biological warfare experiment gone wrong? Shocking!) and full of stock characters you won't remember the names of, but the fact that it takes itself so seriously makes everything that much more enjoyable.

At least the absurdity brought some extra stability along with it, as Riptide is generally a more stable experience than Dead Island: there aren't nearly as many bugs (although there are still some, like quest items not spawning) and weapons don't disappear into the ground nearly as much as they used to. Zombies still clip through walls and each other, but again not quite as much as before. The interface has also gotten a bit of a facelift, and it's less cumbersome to navigate.

Dead Island: Riptide is like pizza: too much of it is bad for you, but you can't resist having just a little bit more. Even if it's the exact same pizza you were eating a few months ago.

reviewText:
This game was a lot of fun! It took all the aspects that I felt made the first game weak, and fixed them. Where to start? Let's start with the regular positives. Like the first game, it is gorgeous! There are more shinies to find and many many mods to make your weapons even more fun to take care of those peskering zombies. You also get to transfer your character from the first game, with all their stats. YAY!
Now the stuff they changed, and they changed and added A LOT! While you still do lots of fetch quests, its not boring. For a change you actually feel you are part of a group. As you fetch items for your fellow immune protagonists and the survivors, it ups your offensive and defensive stats, making you a stronger force when the horde tries to storm your safehouse. This happens various times in key transition points in the game, but you actually see Logan, Sam B, and Purna fighting along side you, along with the other survivors that you help along the way. This makes single player mode feel that you are not alone. I dare say though that this game would still make for a fun multiplayer (I have not played multiplayer). Another positive is the variety of zombies you get to fight. Though you do kill mostly walkers, there are now mutated zombies that prove to be quite the challenge.
Now for the singular negative: the ending. The story wasn't strong to begin with, but it had some interesting twists as it went along. So, the story itself was passable. The ending is open to interpretation as evidenced by many online forums. Everyone has their own view of what happened. My view is that the ending is extremely pessimistic. Hopefully all questions about what happens at the end of the game will be answered in Dead Island 2.
This was a great game, despite the cliffhanger of an ending. It was a fun single player experience and I know that someday I will go back and play as the other protagonists just so I can play this again.

reviewText:
Shiny Textures 2: Return of the Fetch quests

To be honest and keep this short for some people, if you didnt like the first game you wont enjoy this one any better.
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=442448602
This game is a very average sequel and it proves that point often with many dull questlines, faulted gameplay mechanics and real connection with the player.
While the previous game had all of this and probably more, it can mostly be forgiven in my opinion because it was older and didnt have to live up to any previous games.
This wasnt the most popular game when it was released due to some reviewers dumbing things down and critising more than enough to balance the game. But i have had some fun experiences with this game. Being the short zombie Island exploring game that it is, it has much to offer in terms of exploration and side quests aplenty! But note this is an easily short game to binge with others. the ammount of content on offer only goes so far!
This game has an avergage length of 34 hours to 100% complete
Meanwhilte its predessecor has an average time of 46 hours (At least for me.)
The point im trying to make is that if you are looking for any slither of replayability here...good luck.
Enough Briefing, time to boil it down to... The Pros and Cons

Pros:+Original Setting that really nails the tropical environment. (Palanai has 2 main maps and a smaller main-mission area Palanai Mainland, Henderson and Pinai
+Lots of new and improved upgrades! Good for players who liked the blueprints in the first game. The arsenal is expanded to hold various new Zombie Killing Tools! From a Harpoon-gun to Right hand of gloVA (Dev weapon)
+New character to play as! an Australian Badass known as Sergeant John Morgan.
+Locations for the main quest are well suited to the Environment around you.
+Continuation from the First game is simple (Too simple..) and easy to get into.
+Co-Op mode is a must try, it really makes the game a lot more fun! Also you can revive them, trade with them, Create competitions and drive together. It mainly improves the length of riptide's playing life. Also due to the story it makes more sense to have a full team playing all together. (Because they all show up in cutscenes!).
+Explosions and special effects like headshots and simple decapitations look good on normal/high settings. Much,much better than the first game.
+The Skill tree and levelling up in general is handled slowly but is more detailed and rewarding than the first game. The best thing about this is that if you have save data from DI1, you can continue playing with that character! (XP and story only.)
+Collectibles reveal a lot more about the locations that the story cant explain. Some audio logs make references to the events of the first game even.
+It is quite addictive! once you have finished the story you feel obligated to do some sidequests and defeat special enemies to squeeze" out the remaining content!
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=448068305
Cons:-So many damn gameplay issues! What use is introducing new weapons to the game if they break after 20 hits!? also why introduce weapons that are only obtainable after you have completed all the missions?
-Motion blur is a big pain! introduce yourself to the visual and auio settings

reviewText:
Been wanting this kind of game since the first Dead Island came out on XBOX360. Never got a chance to truly buy the game, only tried it. Got tried the Dead Island Riptide, but was not really interested, until the game went sale on steam...

An amazing co op zombie game. You like to play alone? Then you can go scavenge the city, or jungles, or beaches, for weapons, supplies , money, and gears. Let these zombies come crawling into you as you make your way into the urban village or the jungle, dealing one by one with the dead.
You wanna play with other people? Go ahead, gather up to other 3 players on the island where everyone except you and some survivors, are now dead, or becoming the undead.

I love the weapons and how you can improve them. You can scavenge weapons in the wild, or get special weapon as quest reward. Plain weapons can be crafted, modified into any recipes you have found, turn them into better, stronger weapon to suit your playstyle. Melee styles can use blunt or blade weapons, then modify them with electric, fire or poisonous mod. You can also use assault rifles, handgun, and shotgun. You can also activate special skill, Fury, which can be unleashed to kill enemies faster and deadlier.

What's more, you can one shot even tough zombies to the head, perhaps, so far, as I have found, not limited by their level. You can instakill downed zombies with some passive skills for certain characters. Each characters have their own specialty and certain set of skills, ranging from Combat to Survivality. One has blunt weapon specialty, blades, throw weapons, guns, hand to hand,etc. Oh, talking bout level. The zombies also grew stronger and their level will try to match yours, making the game more challenging.

Other friendly players can also jump in into your game, help you out. You can also search the lobby for games with same/lower chapters and you can jump RIGHT INTO IT and  help em out. In the darkness of cave/facility, you can use your flashlight or your flares.

This game is great. Has awesome game mechanics, gameplay, graphics, and storyline.

reviewText:
If you liked the first Dead Island, you'll LOVE this game. This game improves on everything that the first dead island was.

PROS
-Inventory system is improved, you are able to carry more things.
-There is no longer a slight pause when picking up items like in the first game. (At least with small things like money)
-The fighting is even better than in the first game. You can feel the force of every weapon you swing and see the realistic result when you slash across the chest of a zombie and see it get knocked back.
-Guns are VERY useful in this game now, especially compared to the original dead island.
-Graphics are noticeably improved from the first game.
-Lengthy story and world to get immersed in.
-The hilarious bugs from the first game are still here so you get to enjoy all the craziness to its fullness!
-Many fun combat and exploration situations that allow plenty of fun for yourself and friends to share.
-Sam B has a new single

CONS
-Using the same engine as the first game.
-Charged at similar price to the first game when this feels more like The other half" to the original dead island.
-Some plot holes left unfilled by the end of the game. Sequelbating a never-coming sequel
-Some side characters remain very undeveloped and just disappear until the very end of the game.

Overall this was an extremely fun game
date: made even better with friends. I give this a 9/10

reviewText:
If you enjoyed Dead Island then chances are you will enjoy Riptide. If you didn't like the original, then there is nothing here to change your mind on the series.

Riptide takes the original game and makes a series of small tweaks and improvements - adding some new weapons, vehicles, zombies, skills and a new playable character, set on a new but familiar looking island. Combat and gameplay are pretty much the same, with the focus still on melee weapons, though guns and ammo are more widely available.

The hub defence missions are a nice addition, as are the Dead Zones" that contain elite zombies and better loot. Both of these are good fun in coop
date: and you can easily join other players at a similar point in the story.\n\nRiptide doesn't try to reinvent the wheel
recommended: and delivers a solid extension to Dead Island."

reviewText: Dead Island: Riptide is one of the more fun zombie-killing experiences I've had in recent memory.  Building on the formula that made the first game such a hit, Riptide adds several new features and elements that make the second game feel a lot more refined and balanced, while retaining virtually all of the appeal and fun of the first game.\n\nIn fact, I'm pretty sure Riptide is an example of how a game company should handle gamer feedback when making a sequel.  Almost every change made between the first and second game addresses some common complaint from the first.  Health and consumable items no longer take up inventory slots, and won't unequip weapons accidentally.  Firearms are now FAR more useful against the undead, particularly if you follow the age-old advice of aim for the head"
date: but come in enough variety to be accessible early game.  Weapon Mod blueprints are no longer distributed seemingly at random
recommended: and certain weapon mods no longer make weapons so brokenly overpowered to the point of removing the game's challenge.  Basically
hoursPlayed: the entire system has been improved
voteText: dramatically.\n\nThe new additions to the game are also pretty nice.  The new character
helpfulPercent: John
votesHelpful: is a rather fun
votesTotal: playing completely different than any of the other characters
votesFunny: but in a way that is not too hard to figure out (short version: punch everything to make yourself feel better).  Group Fury is also a surprisingly useful (and underrated) ability
commentsCount: which if timed right can literally allow you to bounce between Fury and Group Fury constantly without a break.  The new challenging "Dead Zone" areas are indeed challenging an sort of fun to track down
column16: especially with a group.  And as far as the Siege events go
column17: they too provide an interesting challenge that can be frantic and fun.\n\nDespite all those improvements though
column18: Riptide feels less like a new game and more like an expansion pack.  It also feels smaller than the first
column19: having only two large areas to the first game's three.  While there's more options for how you play
column20: there's not much more to do when you play
column21: though it's not as though that isn't fun.  The game also loses something of the first's ironic charm with the absence of any sort of high-class Resort area.  Aesthetically
column22: part of the first game's appeal was that juxtaposition of idyllic tropical vistas with hordes of rotting undead.\n\nStill
column23: the few problems with the game are a drop in the bucket.  The rest of it is all solidly fun
column24: not to mention replayable.  The game does a great job of adding more good stuff while removing a good deal of the first game's bad stuff. I wouldn't go so far as to call it the clearly superior game
column25: but it is definitely NOT worse than the first.\n\nIn short
column26: if you liked Dead Island for more than just the scenery
column27: you'll like Dead Island: Riptide.  It's just as good as the previous game
column28: delivering more of the same with a variety of welcome additions and improvements."

reviewText:
And I thought the first game was awesome... This game turned out to be even more than 'just' awesome!

let's get started!
I have to say, I expected a bad game. What did I got instead? One that is even  better!  I love it that I can import my DI character from the first game into riptide. Which is awesome!

Why I Like this game?
Gameplay  The gameplay got improved a lot. Sometimes I wonder if I'm playing the first game, or Riptide.

Characters  A new interesting character got added, I can't wait to play as him!

New weapons  They added a bunch of new interesting and awesome looking weapons, from blunt, bladed or range. It's all pretty new.

New skills  they added a bunch of new skills as well! Some are really helpful!

zombies  New types of zombies! Which makes it even more fun!

Beautiful environment  Playing on this island makes me wanna stay there for some odd reason...

These are so far my only positive points of view about this game. But everything has a downside, and so does this game.

The gameplay is a bit the same as the first game. Which isn't surprising of course. The game play is fantastic! Though I found it awesome if it changed a bit. So far? It's realy good actually!

Being level 50+ You can get one-shotted by a thrown knife. Which can be highly iritating.

The extra skins DLC won't be shown much. So it's more useful if you quite often play online.
And yeah, that's about it.  I enjoy every second of the game. It's so much fun to explore, and with the new weapons you can have a lot of fun bashing their brains in! Or.. shoot them off? Cut them off? I don't know...... whatever you like!

See you later!
I hope you'll have a great time playing this game! Because I sure have! Have a nice day!

~Gareth

reviewText:
Not a bad game itself, but it is far from stacking up against the previous one.

The story seems a bit under scripted and repetitive, the locations aren't as developed nor as interesting as Banoi or Moresby, with the flooded jungle being really monotonous.

But at the top of all, the absence of developer mods while still being able to find its items its a great loss in the game.

Overall, mostly recommended for those who haven't played the first one.

reviewText:
This game is really too much of a mixed bag to recommend. While it's fun to kill zombies with weapons you construct the quests are repatitive and simple while somehow also being confusing.

For example, there is a quest where you have to attach an engine to a boat. First the game doesn't actually tell you to find a specific boat, so you wander around slowly with an engine. Then once you realize you need a certain boat it should be simple because there are boats everywhere but no, you need to attach it to a single, unique boat. Except in the map you are given a large radius covering many boats. So when you finally happen to get on the specific boat you see you can attach the engine to different areas. So I attached it to one side of the boat...and nothing happened. So I sat there picking up and putting down the engine. Then I got attacked by zombies and died. So, I respawned away from the boat and made my way back just to literally move the engine from one end of the boat to the other before I was prompted with the next aciton. Sound like fun???

There are good qualities to this game but there are so many tedious tasks, glitches, and unnecessary complexities that it detracdts from the experience.

Hello there, dear Steam users.
This time, I'm going to write a lot of ♥♥♥♥ about:
DEAD ISLAND RIPTIDE.

Let's begin!

tl;dr:
standalone expansion to the original dead island, pretty much better in every aspect, but there are still some bugs left unfixed. in all my playtime, i havent encountered a single game breaking bug. so i guess im just lucky.


SRS BSNS version:
Dead Island Riptide, a standalone expansion to the Dead Island series. It continues RIGHT where Dead Island left off, in a chopper above some sea/ocean/idk, didn't pay attention.
Obviously, Dead Island Riptide wouldn't be a Dead Island game without zombies.
So after the first few cutscenes which totally don't really add anything other than a few minutes to try and attract you to the game, you get control of your picked character.

As this is a direct continuation, you can import a character from the older game, but if it's already max levelled, then you gotta start a new one.
Don't fret, because a new character starts already in level 15, presumably to show off that it actually still remembers something from Banoi.

Location? NOT BANOI. (rip mr. cinnamon lifeguard)
It's time for Palanai! There's a eponymous riptide on the islands, causing nearly everything to be flooded.
Because I have a fetish for water in video games, I've enjoyed this setting much, much more, because there was water EVERYWHERE where I wanted to go!
Then you move to a city and ♥♥♥♥ goes down even more.

The zombie roster has been extended and there's some new ♥♥♥♥♥♥ zombies that don't show off any difficulty at all anyway™
The difficulty" in this game has been increased artificially

reviewText:
Any doubts you may have about this follow-up to one of my fav. games (Dead Island) should be quickly dispelled once you start playing the game.  Yes its basically more of the same, so if you loved playing the original and want a lovely large chunk of some more then you should get this game.  Just dont wait until a sale (like I did) and regret waiting.

Essentially the game is very similar to Dead Island but with a few noticeable differences.  On the whole there isny much of a difference in the look & feel of gameplay.  Changes are subtle such as fast levelling, more streamlined story which provides faster travel between important locations, quicker access to quests and sidequests.  The addition of a new form of transport (boats) is quite cool when navigating the swamp areas, though running over zeds is the same as driving.  The new character (John) provides an additional style of combat (hand-to-hand) which is rather cool is not much different to the other modes of attack.  In addition there are new team based side-quests to help you level up faster on completion.

However the real (noticeable) differences are the better designed map layouts and focused story chapters  which all meld to provide a greatly immersive interactive experience that never feels its dragging on.  Something which the original tended to do as you retraced your steps over and over again.  To cap these off there is a greater feeling of team interaction better the survivors and the group of NPCs that band together in their hope to escape the zombie apocalypse.  These essentially come to a dramatic conclusion at the end of each chapter as big combat sequences where everyone in group must fight of waves and waves of zeds in order to progress.

Despite these positives if you didnt like DI's combat you wont find much has changed.  I loved the visceral feel of the original and as you may expect its the same here.  So if you didnt enjoy it in the original, you wont like it here.  The items and weapons at your disposal are just as lack-lustre as the original - there are no super-juiced-up" items that you must get to complete the game
date: but at least firearms and ammo is available much
recommended: much more here.  So if you missed them in the original you can get to use them alot more here.  Crafting however makes up for the lack of these superweapons and though there were only a v. few new additions
hoursPlayed:
the range of items that can be crafted is excellent.  Allowing you to customize everything to your style of gameplay.

One last suprise which I thought was a really nice step up were the boss areas that you had to go up against and fight to the death.  Nice variation in their abilities provide a good range of challenges against the normal grind against regular zombies.

To finish off Id recommend this game to anyone who loves mission-based action/fps/shooter/melee gameplay in a zombie apocalypse setting.  My only regret was not picking this up on release.  It may not be that much more than the original but
voteText: its definitely a brighter step forward."

reviewText:
After Leaving the infected outbreak on Banoi Island ,in this second installment you escape the island only to be held up on the confines of a military ship were the virus is spreading like wildfire , after this short introduction to the game , you end up washed ashore a tropical island .
The Island itself is quite vast , similair to its predocessor getting from one section of the island to another can be done by boat or Jeep or just the good old fashoined way ...
The game has a breakdown of skilltrees and upgrades combining through 4 different characters, each with there own ability.
The array of Firearms , homemade explosives and hand to hand combat weaponary , is what i personally like very much about  the game , every weapon your get your bloody hands on can be upgraded or customized, offcourse finding some of these parts to customize can be quite the challenge for the novice , have you ever tryd taking a zombies skull , stuck a handle on it , wired a tiny gas bottle a few tweeks here and there ...Hey Presto , we have ourselves a a weapon that even the zombies themselves would be afraid off :)

The Campaign Quests and missions i felt were Lacking Direction , tho kept me quite tentitive and on my toes as i Lurked through gloomy caves and abondoned shacks filled with flesh eating infected. When the going got tough i resorted the to the things i kno best , THAT is brutal savagery , Leaving Limbs and sevred Heads in the wake of my bloody rampage....
Multiplayer CO-OP is the word on most peoples tounge , i however found the co-op sometimes feeling unfinished , glitchy combat at times and the ranking system was kind of a headache , tho with friends this game was really fun online.

Graphically the game has slight improvments with breathtaking landscapes, but playing Riptide on a high-end gaming PC results in a smoother framerate and improved visuals.
I thought DEEP SILVER the developers , Done a satisfactory job with this game , and i will be hoping and waiting for the new installment of the groundbreaking title 8.5/10

reviewText:
New story, new zombies, new ways to explore the Zombie lands. Most of the reviews that are critical I wonder if they played the game as it is so much better than many of the new big ticket games out. This game does have new Zombie types!

It is a polished piece of work with the best zombie physics engine going. rich textures, great sound, amazing detail (water that gets cloudy the deeper you look).

A skill system that shows results immediately. Variable skill zombies, a weapon modification system, repeating quests and re-spawning zombies in public zones to always keep you on your toes. This game can scare the life out of you if you let it.

By far the best Zombie adventure I have played yet. There are not many games that can give you that trapped feeling when the zombies come. This game is a new use of an awesome engine that is a natural extension of the original Dead Island.

reviewText:
Overall a buggy mess. Decent game in its own right, and when it works it's fine, but when it doesn't (which happens more often than not) it'll frustrate you to no end. Bugs like player desync, glitchy collision, and the game just closing itself out entirely can  and will happen quite frequently. Of course, these bugs are absolutely nothing compared to the one where your sound cuts out completely and you're reduced to one frame a second, as well as anyone else that happens to be in the game with you. I'd even go so far as to say it's more buggy than its predecessor.

But onto the game. To be honest, it's what Dead Island should have been in the first place. Guns are actually present way earlier than they were in the first game, and there are definitely a variety of different kinds of weapons to fight your way through the undead with. But through the games shoddy dialogue and dumb writing comes a mediocre Borderlands wannabe. Not very enjoyable in a solo run, more something to be played with friends.

Buy it on sale. Play with friends. Otherwise, not worth it. At least it has simple achievements.

reviewText:
My recommendation is dependant on a couple of factors.

First, did you like the original? If you did, then you'll probably enjoy this one. However, if you did like the original, don't expect this one to be nearly as good or as long. Just...don't.

Secondly, do you like killing zombies, collecting loot, exploring, and most importantly, endless fetch quests? If you like the first three, and can tolerate the last one, then you'll probably enjoy this game.


Pros:
Zombie slaying, loot gathering, rpg leveling, skill acquiring goodness.
It's co-op!
You can get sniper rifles and own everything late game as Purna.
You can stomp on a zombie's head when it's on the ground! Y'know, if you've got the required skill from the skill tree.
There are new areas called 'dead zones' which are chock full of enemies and multicolored loots. Explore!
Our four main survivors from the first game return...sadly, they still are unlikeable jerks for the most part.
Weapon mods! Create custom weapons to rival the gods of fire or thunder.
Gore, lots and lots of it.
Sam B produces a new hit single! Yeah, I'm just as shocked as you are.
Drivable boats!
Drivable cars! Make those zombies roadkill.
Gun alternatives for Purna early game. First game needed this SO MUCH.
A brand new immune named John joins the group. He has a sweet uppercut move.
New enemy types, including named boss type infected that are SUPER ANNOYING, but they're good fun to fight.
Throwing knives that stack.
Removal of alcohol from the weapon wheel. Very helpful.
Improved inventory organization. Grenades and other throwables no longer use up weapon inventory spaces. SO NICE.


Cons:
Severe lack of fast travel locations. You know what this means? Length padding. Trek back and forth and back and forth and back and forth through areas you've been a million times before killing the same damn enemies over and over again because  it artificially lengthens a relatively short game.
Repetitive. My goodness is it repetetive. Still fun, but it's best not to play in lengthy sessions.
A brand new cast of completely disposable NPC's who order us around incessently and we consequently don't give a rats ♥♥♥♥ what happens to them.
One-shot kill glitch from cleaver throwing zombies. Do yourself a favor and download the mod that shuts that off.
Dead zones are basically copy/pasted from each other instead of making truly unique locations for each. I think I cleared the same basement in the city about 15 times.
Significant lack of human enemies. In the zombie apocalypse you have zombies, and '@ssholes with guns'. There are almost no humans to fight. Never thought I'd miss it, but a little more variety would be nice, y'know?
Half the length of the first game.
Still no in-game ability to change the FOV settings. If you follow the online guides and like to shoot things, don't set FOV to 90 cause it causes your guns to go crazy if you aren't using iron sights. Set it 82.5. It worked for me.
Loot settings are whacked. Apparently it's almost impossible to get the legendary items without modding the game due to drop restrictions.
Severe overuse of running infected. Really lessens the impact of the running screaming ones if you throw them at me absolutely everywhere I go instead of saving them to jump me at unexpected moments like in the first game.
Audio glitches abound. Female zombies sound like male zombies. Floaters roar like Thugs. Suiciders sometimes sound like Floaters. More extensive QA testing would've been very helpful.
Got trapped by an NPC blocking a doorway once.
Generally weaker atmosphere, graphics, and overall presentation than the original.
That ending: Dear Techland, Learn how to write endings that aren't total sequel bait. Thank you.


Final verdict? 7/10
It's not as fun as the first one. It's shorter than the first one. Everything feels like a rehash of the original despite the new weapons and enemy types. The atmosphere is significantly weaker as well. In the original Dead Island, there was a palpable feeling of despair from the survivors. NPC's huddled in corners, some of them weeping, sometimes rocking back and forth hugging their knees, sometimes praying or comforting each other. The survivors feel and act like they are an inch from death and there was almost nowhere in the first game I truly felt safe.

In this one? Man, nobody cares much. It's like everyone knows they're in a sequel. Where's the horror? The panic? The pandemonium? First game has it in spades, but the second just doesn't. It just feels like the devs rushed it out the door. Every now and then I get a glimpse of the original through all this mediocre stuff they clogged the second game up with, but these occurances are few and far between.

If you wanna kill zombies, Riptide does a pretty good job of it. However, if you want a true zombie survival horror experience, go download the first game and go for a walk by the hotel in a dark room while you're wearing headphones. You'll see immediately what I'm talking about with the atmosphere.

This game is not bad or anything, it just suffers from that most dreadful of things, 'sequelitus'.

reviewText:
If you enjoyed the original Dead Island but you're on the fence of buying this game like I was, you probably might like it, or probably not.

The FOV is pretty low, but you can download a utility mod found in the steam forums to increase the FOV (and disable shadows completely to get an FPS boost), so that's not much of a problem.

While I do enjoy the gameplay still (slashing katanas never gets old). In comparison to the original Dead Island, the game feels much more linear by comparison, the overall game world feels much more fenced in in comparison to the more open areas of Moresby and the Beach Resort in the Original. You don't have much way of exploration in this sense, and if you do the side missions, you pretty much been to everywhere there is to go. The athmosphere of everything going to hell like it should be is still here like in the original, but it just feels too linear for my tastes, and the open world exploration is what I liked in the original, but there's a lot less here.

The game also somehow manages to feel more unoptimized than it's predecessor, as I constantly experienced microstutter.

If you liked the original Dead Island to the point where you spent 100+ hours playing it you might feel different and still probably find a way to enjoy the game. Anyone else shouldn't really bother. I played the original Dead Island to the point where I got the extremely rare orange weapons (like the Eviscerator). But overall I personally don't find it worthwhile even when the game is constantly on sale for $7.49.

reviewText:
Dead Island Riptide feels like a big DLC for the original Dead Island, rather than being a standalone game.
That being said the game is still fun, and worth your time playing it, if you enjoyed the first Dead Island.
If you didn't like the first game, then avoid this one, because it won't change your opinion about the franchise. But if you had a fun time with Dead Island, and want more, then Riptide is a good choice.

PROS:
- Graphics are slightly improved since the first Dead Island.
- The storm mechanics is an interesting touch to the game.
- Mini dungeon system introduced.
- Slashing zombies and looting stuffs are still fun.
- A couple of new enemy types introduced.
- New survivor added.
- The game carries over your Dead Island safe file, allowing you to keep your current level and skill build.


CONS:
- World map feels smaller than the previous Dead Island
- Story is short and somewhat disappointing.
- No variety in missions: you will be doing item fetching most of the time.
- Survivor character animations could have been way better.
- Riptide inherited the same glitches the first game had.
