reviewText:
This is my spoiler-free, unbiast review of the game after giving it a nice speedrun.

The Good:

- Decent graphics for a game of its time, running off Directx9
- Game is well optimized for older systems (DX9)
- 4 Player Based Co-Op Zombie Horror/Adventure game
- Lots of weapons and loot to customize, as collectables and rarities to find
- Despite weapon tiers, the game is fairly forgiving in terms of loot
- Client-Sided Level systems keep the game balanced and fun for all players
- Game is equally as fun in both Singleplayer and Multiplayer
- You can port your previous characters from Dead Island if you're story-driven or want continuity
- Different characters, abilities, attributes, and skill tree options give the game a lot of more variety

The Bad:
- Allthough it has some open-world qualities and side quests, the game feels pretty linear overall. Progression felt very fast through each chapter (especially multiplayer) and I found the Final boss fight to be higly disappointing and anti-climactic in Multiplayer, and just more daunting to accomplish in Singleplayer.
- Gameplay itself felt really simple and reptitive, talk to this guy, do this quest, complete it, and return for your reward. Animations felt simple and reptitive, but still pretty fluid overall.
- The game did have 13 chapters, but progression felt too quick and the game felt short overall, even if finish the game and return to do any side quests, It doesn't really feel the same anymore. You left the island and escaped, only to return for a few side quests and blueprints? Wat.
- If you don't really don't know how to craft powerful weapons or find the right blueprints, the game is going to be pretty hard for you, whereas if you do know what you're doing, the game is fairly easy, regardless of level progression.
- If you don't have a Dead Island 1 character, the game starts you at Level 15 by default and if you didn't choose a preset skill tree, which sorta makes you feel cheated out of the level system.

The Ugly:

- Realizing you lost all your money from dying because you neglected to use your medkits.
- Fear my Legendary Liquid Fire Poisionous Stinky Lightning Shock Rod of Justice!
- Leaving someone behind in a car or on a boat to get mauled by zombies.
- Having to fight the same final boss 4 times in a row.
- Realizing your melees are more effective than actual firearms.
- Hearing zombies scream as you burn or shock them alive...er dead.
- Realizing the special infected/minibosses" are Left 4 Dead 2 or Killing Floor zombie ripoffs.
- Getting mauled by zombies? Have an energy drink! Heals all wounds!

Final Review:

Overall

reviewText:
Dead Island Riptide feels like an add-on to Dead Island. It looks and plays exactly the same, but has some minor improvements and fixes (not everything is fixed I'm afraid, it still has some weird bugs) in comparison to the original game. Plus, it's located on a different island and has an extra playable character. Since Riptide allows you to import your character using a savegame from the first game I haven't had the chance yet to play with this new character.

The island itself doesn't differ that much from the first island. I mean, it's still some sort of holiday resort and yes, halfway through the game you'll be running around villages and old bunkers, similar to the original game.

The game is best played with friends, or coop partners in general, because you'll mostly get slaughtered regularly when you're on your own. Playing with friends makes the game more fun and a bit more challenging and doing the sidequests feel less like a chore when played with others.
Riptide has more than enough content to make it stand out as a retail game, and not as an add-on. There are tons of sidequests and you can level up to level 70. The main story should also take quite a while to complete, about 10-15 hours I'd say.

Anyway, why change a winning formula, right ? The killing of zombies by using melee weapons just feels right, no matter if everything else looks and feels the same. This game has some great combat, really great.

If you enjoyed DI you'll definitely enjoy this one as well.

[Rating: 78/100]

reviewText:
RIptide is the sequel to Dead Island (more like a big DLC). Aside from the whole new map and a new playable character, it's pretty much the same game with some new weapons, moves and zombie types. If you played the first Dead Island, you can import your character and it will come with the skills you previously owned. This game is shorter and easier, especially if you have your imported you save game. The base defense missions are the best bits of the game.

I recommend Riptide if you think your experience with Dead Island wasn't enough already. If it's your first time going for Dead Island, stick with the first one: it's longer and has better quests. You won't miss too much.

And go for coop on this one, it's less boring that way!

reviewText: So as a fan of both the firts Dead Island and Dead island riptide I loved it. If you're looking for a great and immense story this is not the game for you. I love the RPG element of this game especially the ability to upgrade and mod your weapons to add an extra punch to the zombies. The game has some flaws especially the attrocious jumping system (you don't use it much, but it can get annoying). Absolutely reccomend playing this co-op with at least 1 friend as it makes the game that much more fun. If you enjoyed the original dead island, you're gonna love this one!

reviewText: I was five years old when I began to drink. Home life wasn't that great, my mother had died from super AIDS while giving birth to me. Everyday I come back home to a dirty box from my full time job down at the local kitten factory where I work my fingers to the bone making kittens. It really isn't the best way to live. I looked straight into the man's eyes even though his angelic beauty threatened to blind me. He reached out his arm with his index finger extended, and, touching my extended finger, spoke the words that shall forever be engraved in my mind that will carry me through my darkest hour: Who do you voodoo

reviewText:
I am writing this reveiw from a standpoint of finishing both it and it's predessesor. In many ways, DIR is a copy-and-paste of the original DI, with a list of subtle differences and a different island, NPCs, and quest line. One might say it is more of a stand-alone expansion, taking into consideration that you can transfer your DI character to DIR AND that it picks up right from where DI left off. And that is how I will treat this reveiw, by continuing from where my DI reveiw left off, covering the old and new aspects of DIR.

I finished Dead Island in 25 hours, doing a select majority of sidequests. I finished Dead Island Riptide in 16 hours, doing a select majority of sidequests. With the release of DIR, none of the glitches from the first game were fixed, and seemingly more followed them as well. And because of the fact that this game was like a copy-and-paste of the original, this and all of the badly designed systems were transfered as well. The aspects that differed from the first game include:

A few new perks on the skill tree.
A new character to play as.
A few new weapons.
An array of quests that differ from each other in almost no way at all.
Harlow is hotter than Jin.
Your character is half-mutant in the late game, but you only even get to experience it twice and for a very short moment.
Less variety of guns.
A few new crafting mods.
Only one firefight in the whole game.
Lots of wading through water, which makes you way slower.
The world is significantly small.
The new Dead Zone random missions (a good concept, actually, but they are all the same exact room with different loot and different exteriors, and so in the end a pretty aweful concept.
Periodic tower defense which is surprisingly not that bad of a concept.
Harlow is a ♥♥♥♥♥.
You can do favors for your AI team to upgrade their skills or their shops.

In my opinion, lots of things made the game much worse than Dead Island, even with the few new concepts. I feel, however, that this game should be looked at the same as DI: terrible, glitchy, and a hell of alot of fun with friends. I will never again play through this game or DI, but neither do I regret playing it. On sale for about $5, I reccomend getting it, but only after playing through DI, or else there's no point in causing pain to yourself. Overall, I hate this ♥♥♥♥ing game, but it was one of the most memorable experiences in my life. So, get a few copies, kill some 'monsters', as the NPCs call them, and loot all the oleander your digestive system can handle. Oh, and the ending was ♥♥♥♥ing awesome. GO4SALE.

reviewText:
One of my favorite RPG games!

Game is open world RPG zombies which allows you to free roam. It is probably created to play co-op with friends and have some fun. Playing alone can be a bit boring. Every character in game has skill tree and levels. Killing zombies and completing missions will increase your XP and levels. With levels you will be able to upgrade your character's skill tree. Map is really big and it has more cities. While playing you can find mods and with them you can craft your weapons. It is the second part from Dead Island franchise and it continues story from Dead Island 1. If we compare it with Dead Island 1, Dead Island Riptide has a lot of new improvements such as new vehicles, characters, skills, weapons, mods, zombies, styles of missions and more levels.

Game is worth of money and i reccommend it to everyone who wanna have some fun with killing zombies and playing co-op with friends. If you want to know whole story you will need to buy also Dead Island 1.
9,5/10

reviewText: Dead Island Riptide is the sequel to the original Dead Island, a bug ridden mess that survived on it's beautiful open world environments and the joy you get from bashing in a Zombie's skull with an electrified shovel. Riptide starts out quite a bit ahead of the original by releasing with only the bare minimum of game breaking bugs but this is unfortunately also the only thing that Riptide really does better than it's original.\n\nYou start off the game being able to pick one of the four original characters, or in fact import you old Dead Island character if you so desire although all you really get is the levels. You can also pick the newly introduced John" character who's specialty seems to be electric knuckles. After a quick tutorial
date: reintroducing you to the various concepts of the game you are then thrown onto the island of Palanai which is pretty much exactly the same as Banoi was in the original
recommended: a tropical paradise overrun by zombies.\n\nAs you start to move through the beaches
hoursPlayed: jungles
voteText: lagoons and cities of Palanai you will be hard pressed to tell that you are playing a new game and not just a reskin of the original. Everything looks and feels the same as it did the last time you played and there is very little new to be found. The scenery is still beautiful
helpfulPercent: the zombies still have no AI
votesHelpful: the missions are still dull and the NPC's still make you want to hurt people.\n\nWhat little new is introduced is of little consequence to the overall feel of the game. A rather big portion of the quests are now "team" quests which are just fetch quests that the developers didn't bother to add any dialog to
votesTotal: essentially you run off and find specific crafting components which allows you to upgrade the weaponry/stores of the people that travel with you from camp to camp. Upgrading the weapons of these people tie into the new base defense type missions that will subject you to an increasingly strong horde trying to overrun your camp
votesFunny: the better weapons your team has the more efficient they are at fighting off the undead on their own
commentsCount: unfortunately it makes little difference in the end and you will most likely end up killing everything on your own regardless.\n\nBoats are also a new addition to the formula which are essentially cars that handle worse and that you can get pulled out if you fall asleep or forget to use the extremely forgiving quicktime event. A few new special zombies are introduced
column16: such as the Screamer who's high pitched voice make you unable to defend yourself for several seconds
column17: the Grenadier that throws explosives pieces of himself at you and the Wrestler who doesn't actually wrestle you but swings his one oversized arm around like a sledgehammer. A number of named "unique" zombies also populate the island
column18: mostly in the new special dungeons called "Dead Zones" however these are just regular zombies that have been beefed up with more health or speed.\n\nAll in all Dead Island Riptide is nothing more than an overpriced standalone expansion pack that adds nothing of note that you didn't already see in the original and even for people new to the franchise I would still recommend playing the original instead of this as it provides much more content for the price."

reviewText:
DEAD ISLAND RIPTIDE
Standalone continuation to Dead Island that's more an expansion than a full blown sequel

Rating 6/10

The original Dead Island was an enjoyable experience despite it's numerous flaws. Riptide addresses a few of these failings but it's essentially more of the same. It starts badly with a clichéd corrupt corporate suit and a conspiracy; thankfully however it's not the plot that drives Dead Island but the exploration, loot and combat. For all its poor writing and characterisation the setting is still superbly realised, a sun-drenched tropical island with just enough variation in locales to keep it interesting. Combined with the great combat and looting and there's still a lot to recommend with Riptide.

Apart from fixing a few bugs and being more stable the most noticeable changes to the formula are the addition of new transport, a zombie horde mode which happens at key moments as the story progresses and a handful of new zombie threats.

The new mode of transport is a small boat (Think: Far Cry 2) It's a nice twist as towns and regions are now submerged and wading through water will slow you down. The boat allows you to quickly move around but its noise attracts fast water borne zombies called drowners. This new threat makes sure you don't really feel safe as they can clamber onto the boat and pull you off. It also addresses the problem in the original Dead Island of the invincibility of the vehicles.

There is also a new zombie horde mode although it only appears occasionally throughout the story. Each defensible area can be protected with barbed wire fences, heavy-MG turrets and booby traps such as electrical traps. Various NPCs will also take part in this horde defense and it requires a certain level of micro management, running around checking each NPC is handling him/herself and dealing with any threats they can't handle. They aren't particularly difficult and far too simplistic to really add anything to the game.

The new mutated zombies include wrestlers, grenadiers, drowners and screamers. Each new zombie poses a different threat. Whilst not a big change to the game play they do keep you on your toes, run into a screamer (think: The Siren from Killing Floor) at the wrong time and it can leave you defenseless which combined with other threats such as the infected can cause a few problems.

Even though there's less variation than Dead Island there's still more than enough to keep you busy. Numerous fetch quests, loot and exploration will keep you busy for hours and the combat remains a satisfying experience as you chop of limbs and stamp on heads.

I believe both Dead Island and Riptide are best played solo. Playing co-op is a completely different beast. Played solo Riptide is a tense game, one of fear and always looking over your shoulder. Played with friends it turns it into more of a fun fair, who can chop up the zombies faster than the other players with no tension and no sense of fear. So to best experience Dead Island I would recommend you skip the co-op and delve into what is still the best open-world zombie game available.

reviewText:
I really do like this game. Although some people choose to slag it off because it is literally a reskin. I personally believe this game is great. I put enough time into this game to reach level 50. There is alot of pros and many cons but this game is still great and really is a good edition to the zombie genre. The story is weak but gameplay is great and for that i will get straight to the point and list pros and cons.

Pros:
Great gameplay
Nice loot system
Decent crafting mechanic
Great Replayabillity (If i spelt that correct)
Awesome new weapons and mechanics which improve upon its last game

Cons
Blank story
Some plot holes
Plain and sometimes dumb AI

Final verdict:
Do buy this game. Its fun and simple to get used to. Dont let my cons put you off, The story really isn't bad but it does leave gaps. Enjoy!

reviewText:
Awesome game!  I would still recommend playing the first, but the second was leagues above for me.

Pros
- Better mods, better skills overall, and weapon proficiencies were added
- Better story than the first
- Moving about the island.  Not as static and boring as the first
- Defense rounds are fun and challenging
- New enemies
- Upgrading of NPC team members and merchants

Cons
- Some physics off.  Hiding behind a steel cart, guy swings horizontally and squashes me as if the cart didn't exist.  NPC trapped me in their hidey hole so I had to restart.  Ladders sometimes a little clunky.
- Pretty predictable storyline.  Maybe zombie scripts are all played out?
- Repeatable quests - why do they give so much xp?!  Bringing a can of food back should not trump main questline rewards.
- Needs more fast travel points in the first half of the game.  Too much travel time v. quest/story.
- Zombie ninja skills - this was weird.  So zombies throw weapons (a few did in the first one).  However, they are freakin' ninja assassins with these things.  One shotted at full health from a normal mob.  Zombies in water - physics don't apply to the undead didn't you know?  These guys run full sprint speed in waist deep water.  Lazy development - give us a reason they move just as fast in the water as they do on land.

Still haven't played multiplayer with buddies, but looks like a blast.  Highly recommend.

reviewText:
Riptide is, from a cold perspective, a new dose of the same...  but it's not in any way a bad thing. If you liked Dead Island you'll like Riptide.

To me it seems like it's quite a bit harder than the first game was, what will make it sometimes kinda frustrating. But a good a thing is you can import your character from Dead Island so you don't have the sensation you're starting over at all. You won't have your inventory but the skills you worked so hard to get will be there!

Overall it's not a bad game but could be a lot better. It definitely lacks innovation, something new to set it apart from its predecessor. It just feels like you're playing a Dead Island DLC or something. It's still worth playing though.

I'd give it a 6,5/10 or so.

reviewText: I had alot of fun playing this game with my friend, we saw it as an ongoing project really. However, there are many bugs in this game. Not so many to make it unplayable, just to make it REALLY annoying. In one of the key missions you have to climb up a ladder and it wouldn't let me. It kept throwing me off halfway up. Had to restart. ZOMBIES GLITCH THROUGH ♥♥♥♥ING WALLS. WTF? PLAYERS CAN GLITCH THROUGH ♥♥♥♥ING WALLS! And little annoying af glitches like when you climb down a ladder you right leg freezes just kinda make me think it was a bit of a slap-dash game. With a bit more work, the plain ♥♥♥♥ing annoying glitches could've been removed and it would have become a much better game. It also would've been nice not to be locked out of the campaign when you complete it. We focused on the main story and when we completed it we couldn't use any of our weapons again or complete the side quests we left. But, if you're looking for a fun game and aren't too bothered by fairly tame glitches then sure this game is alot of fun :)

reviewText:
Riptide is, from a cold perspective, a new dose of the same...  but it's not in any way a bad thing. If you liked Dead Island you'll like Riptide.

To me it seems like it's quite a bit harder than the first game was, what will make it sometimes kinda frustrating. But a good a thing is you can import your character from Dead Island so you don't have the sensation you're starting over at all. You won't have your inventory but the skills you worked so hard to get will be there!

Overall it's not a bad game but could be a lot better. It definitely lacks innovation, something new to set it apart from its predecessor. It just feels like you're playing a Dead Island DLC or something. It's still worth playing though.

I'd give it a 6,5/10 or so.

reviewText:
I agree with alot of other people here,  This is a good game...

So if you like Open world games, and Love Zombie games, and you like co-op games... HERE YA GO!!!

Sure who didnt like Left for dead, this is diffrent, this is more open world, more throws you in there like youre really there, guess what that Led pipe you pulled off the building for a weapon, ya you crush enough heads in, and its gonna break unless you repair it. !

This game has a nice RPG feel to it, Mod Weapons, Craft, repair, Sell, etc...

Level up, put those points in Survival or maybe you think youre badass and go more Combat style, its all good and all fun!

Heres some pro's and cons
+great Co-op
+RPG
+Open World
+love the crafting, and repair mechanic of wep's
+Story, ok so the story isnt the best, but its still kinda cool, and doesnt just say here, heres a gun, kill the zombies!
there is a story to it, and you learn more as you progress and   help people
+Graphics are decent for an older game
+go for a blow to the head, arm, leg, take them out diffrent ways, with diffrent weapons, makes a diffrence, and its fun!
+Love to pick between diffrent charaters and have diffrent abilities, but not a huge game changer, just a diffrent play style
+It is better then the first one, I think... a lttle more polished, game doesnt crash on co op experiance

Cons
-have had a few crashes on co-op, but has gotten much better
-Open world is nice, but still somewhat go this way or that way.  Well alot of the zones, but for the most part its open world
-found a few glitches with zombies getting stuck in a wall or two, not a big issues thou, 2 or 3 times i think so far
-Driving a car seems very stiff, and dont leave your car far if you have items in the back, things tend to dispawn you go to far from them, but the nice thing, items reset too, so you are able to loot the same bodies or containers again...

In my oppion a good game to pick up and play with friends... Its been a while since i was on edge of my seat playing a game, and about jumped when was ambushed by  a zombie floating what seemed to be dead in the water when i went to loot something nearbye,   was awsome!

reviewText: I liked the original Dead island and with this sequel I was hoping for something new. Unfortunately I hardly got something new. Sure, slaying zombies remains fun but I could do the same in the prequel. Also this game seems to punish you for not playing in co-op as the difficulty doesn't seem to adjust itself when playing with/without other people. The story is mediocre, even with the new character. The boats are fun for what they are but aren't such a necessity.\nOverall a very average game that could have been great but it feels like just a reboot of the original

reviewText: More undead enemies to slaughter any way you like! I found this game to be a slight bit more difficult than it's predecessor, Dead Island. But that is because of the new, more crowded environments and new enemies that beat you if you're not careful. With these new things, this game is, in my opinion, better than the first Dead Island. The map can be confusing at times, due to the amount of rivers and such. I had tons of fun playing through the story, and there's still many quests to complete afterwards. I definitely recommend this title to any zombie slaying fan!

reviewText:
In this game will continoue the story of previous Dead Island game in near island Palanai and you will learn more things about the origin of the virus. You can fight new infected and bosses. Also if you play single player you can see and fight with the other survivors in some missions, something that it didn't exist in previous game. They are team missions in single player where you can make the AI survivors stronger if you find every time the right items and give them to them. In multiplayer you can still see the other survivors and fight with them until someone join and take the place of the AI survivor.

reviewText: New story, new zombies, new ways to explore the Zombie lands. Most of the reviews that are critical I wonder if they played the game as it is so much better than many of the new big ticket games out. This game does have new Zombie types! It is a polished piece of work with the best zombie physics engine going. rich textures, great sound, amazing detail (water that gets cloudy the deeper you look). A skill system that shows results immediately. Variable skill zombies, a weapon modification system, repeating quests and re-spawning zombies in public zones to always keep you on your toes. This game can scare the life out of you if you let it.

reviewText:
7.5 / 10
Great game a little short when it comes to the story. As I am half way through and I mostly played with one person on average. Looks great. Decent-to-good story. The extra characters don't do much for replayability without unique story paths for each character.
My one suggestion, as always, is a 'Apocalypse! What Apocalypse?' mode/DLC.
Each area has a set number of living dead that must be destroyed to cleanse the island with bonus points awarded for saving those still alive and for keeping them alive until the end.

reviewText:
This game is kind of slightly above average game. While I had lots of fun smashing and ripping zombies apart, the story was  mediocre at best, the main quests were good while the side quests seemed tedious and plain boring, most of them were fetch quests and I really didn't like them as they were much of a chore than having fun.
The graphics of this game is good although, sometimes feels a bit plastic and recycled textures throughout the game. Although, the good thing about this game is that it runs smooth even on my old computer which is great for me.
The weapon crafting system seemed OK, although they could have improved it a bit. The skill system was kinda good, but lacked in variety or new abilities.
Overall, the game was kind of above the average I did have a lot of fun and didn't find any technical difficulties , apart from a few glitches, which is no problem, and it ran smooth , that's a great thing for me since I am stuck with an old computer, although be ready for an average story though the game play is great.

It rate it 7/10.

reviewText:
The zombie genre has been exhausted similarly to my Dead Island character after swinging his baseball bat a little too many times. There's simply just been too much saturation and too much cliche.

What makes Dead Island Riptide so different?

Lets go back in time. The Original Dead Island was a game about a group of immune surivors who discover that throwing a weapon is far more effective at maintaining durability than actually using it as a weapon, than abusing it to the extreme. These survivors then go on to throw a sequel.

Fast forward to Dead Island Riptide, What has changed?

The answer is absolutely everything. In a sudden stroke of coincidental circumstance, suddenly throwing a weapon can magically make weapons disappear and the world comes crashing down on them. Desperate for a new strategy their saviour comes in the form of a foul mouthed Australian who demonstrates how we treat each other in Australia; bashing them because they're different.

Led by the newfound Australian Bruce Lee they proceed to curbstomp every zombie from one side of the island to another, proving that once again Australian politeness is applicable to every race and culture.

As you can see Dead Island Riptide is not simply a zombie game. It is much deeper and broader than the zombie genre. Dead Island Riptide is an accurate and insightful game into Australian mannerisms, culture and traditions and will leaving you wondering 'Where the bloody hell are ya?'

reviewText:
This game... I can't put it into words but there's something wrong about this game. What Dead Island: Riptide should be in theory is just Dead Island 1 with a new setting and a new coat of paint. But for some reason unknown to me, it just feels BAD.

That's not to say it's a bad game, I'm sure others found it plenty fun, but in my mind, the enjoyment I had playing Dead Island just didn't carry over to this game. It feels very clunky, I have trouble walking from point A to point B. The quest dots that you followed in DI, which you became reliant on to determine what route to take and where to explore, just doesn't seem to work anymore. There's an option to turn it off and on, but really sometimes it works, and sometimes there's nothing. I often times miss attacks that SHOULD have connected, but didn't for some arbitrary reason, and that gives combat a layer of tedium that'll make you avoid any interaction with the zombies you can.

If you liked DI, sure, maybe you'll like this one. It is pretty much the same game. But to me, it's feels like... It feels like going to a restaurant you've been to before which you really liked, and eating your meal and not enjoying it like you did before.

TL;DR - If you played Dead Island, you'd probably like this one, but something felt off in my playing of it. Buy it when it's on sale preferably, and skip the DLC. they don't really contribute much.

reviewText: I have been a huge fan of the original, and Dead Island Riptide kept most of what I wanted from it with GREATLY improved mechanics, saw this was on sale and didn't hesitate to buy it. I don't really recommend it to new players who did not play the first one, since it can get kind of hard and tedious at times, although for hardcore DI fans like me, they will like it very much. The first part of the game will be kind of boring although once you progress through the story and start getting better weapons and such, you will have such a blast blowing off zombie heads and cutting their limbs. As for the story it was pretty interesting although the final boss was not that great. The base defense missions were also pretty fun.\n\n8.5/10

reviewText: This is pretty much the exact same thing as Dead Island. The only thing they changed was the combat system and all they did was add levels for specific weapons and new weapons. The story sucks and is drawn out.The voice acting sucks. All the quests are pretty much get me x and ill give you y". I'm pretty sure there's less quests in this game than the first. One thing that annoys me is how in the first game there's multiple groups of people in different places
date: so there are more side quests. In this one you just move from place to place with your group
recommended:
so there's pretty much no side quests. The environment sucks in this game. The city is awful compared to the first one. Unless there's a story quest you don't run into bandits. The jungle is flooded with little boats so you have to walk extremely slow in the water. The game feels rushed consisting of a lot of bugs. They could have added so much to make the game good but they just made Dead Island 1.5.


Why you should wait for a massive price cut or avoid altogether:

1. If you were severely disappointed by the first one and told yourself you'd only buy a sequel if they made improvements because the ones made (fire weapons actually give light in this game) are minimal and not a enough to warrant a purchase.

2. Glitches abound

3. The story defeats itself on many levels (it's also boring and confusing)

4. There is zero improvement on the combat mechanics

5. Zombies respawn even after rooms and spaces have been cleared

6. You were hoping for more "survival horror" elements; they were nearly completely removed from this game"

reviewText:
See my Dead Island review for the shared basics: excellent melee system (makes up for all the negatives), pretty good looting and crafting system. Infuriating UI and consolitis.

Riptide is almost the same experience but with some improvements. The biggest I can think of is that firearms now feel genuinely powerful against zombies, and are now a legitimate choice. The weapon category leveling allows you to enjoy all sorts of weapons no matter which character you choose to play.

You can import your DI character into Riptide and continue leveling it.

The locations in Riptide: The first half are pretty crap, the second half are pretty good.
You see all these screenshots of the characters in the swamp? You're going to HATE that swamp. You can't sprint, you just slosh around, and you're gonna be doing a lot of walking back and forth. Yes there are motor boats, and maybe you can drive one for ten seconds before zombies pull you out into the water in an impossible QTE.

I still enjoyed this game plenty. It carries the positives AND the negatives of DI, with some improvements, not enough improvements sadly. But it's still DI, a bit better, and I love DI. Meleeing (and now shooting) feel just awesome.

reviewText:
I loved the first Dead Island game, but this... is... horrible.

First of all, the one thing I hate the most is: This game gives me MOTION SICKNESS! I'm not sure why, maybe it's the framerate, maybe it's the swingy first-person camera whenever you do anything... Seriously, the character will move around when idle for too long, and FFS the camera swing along! The camera swings FOR EVERY SINGLE F-ing melee attack!

I can't play for more than 2 hours per session. Gives me the headache.

The storyline is a sequel to the first game, and much similar to the first game, it's an open world melee zombie basher game with bunch of fetch quests.

But then, I gotta rant for some of the level designs.

The maps are huge, and the travel distance between the quest giver and the quest destination are often very far away, so there will be a whole lot of walking and climbing and jumping. Plus, the mini-map navigation line is broken, unlike the first game. You gotta be very near to the destination before the waypoint guide will appear.

Jungle swamp area are damn full of waterway that you can't run (you can only walk). A waste of time traveling between areas.

Tunnels are too damn dark you gotta keep using flares to light the whole room in red, which is super annoying especially when you activate your fury.

City areas are too complicated especially without a navigation guide. You can't plan your route with the map because often the map will not show blockage. Much like a real-world GPS.

The new enemy Screamer" is a pain-in-the-♥♥♥.

The import character from first game feature makes the game harder instead of easier. It only imports your level and skills
date: but not equipments. So you'll start up with a high level character with no godlike weapons. The enemy scale with your level
recommended: so good luck with that.\n\nThe mouse sensitivity is not consistent. When set to my most comfortable acceleration for FPS
hoursPlayed: walking and melee attack is fine
voteText: but menu navigation is too fast
helpfulPercent: while aiming with guns are too slow. Bad console port.\n\nIf you're collecting achievements and perfecting games
votesHelpful: all achievements are very doable
votesTotal: but the in-game achievement tracker is buggy as hell and some of the quest won't register itself especially if you're playing over the internet. So if you're unlucky
votesFunny: you might need to replay the whole game over and over again to find out which quest got glitched.\n\nLastly
commentsCount:
a lot of plots make no sense.
Example: Why do you have to burn the cinema films when you can just burn one of the sofa or the bundle of wood on the roof?

Very bad game.

My score: 2/10"

reviewText:
It's hard to find good things about this game but I'll try my best. Here's the game in general:

Pros-Fluid Combat System (This makes up most of the cons, honestly).
-Very fun if played with friends.
-Lots of Weapons to use. Lots of mods to try on your disposal.
-You can choose which main character you want to play. Each with their own special abilities.
-More Special Zombies from the first game.

Neutral-RPG elements (A zombie game with leveling up system. Original but it feels weird)
-Dated Graphics (It's not too bad, Character and Zombie Models look ok, only the Textures look bad)
-Difficulty Spikes (Many people complained about this. It's not really a BIG problem. Most RPG games always have that)

Neutral-Con-Boring Missions, Awesome Rewards
-The Mini-Map will confuse you but the Big Map won't.

Cons-Horrible Options (Go and download Dead Island Riptide Helper, it will fix most graphical and control problems)
-Buying items are better than Looting
-Bad Animations during cutscenes
-Lots of Loading screen
-Boring if played alone
-Story's too short
-Buying stuff will be VERY EXPENSIVE if you reach the ending of the game.

VerdictIt's basically the first Dead Island but with a different map. If you ever had a choice to buy either Dead Island. PICK THE FIRST DEAD ISLAND. This one's more boring.
I still think it's a good CO-OP game. So buy 2 for a friend.

6/10

reviewText:
Super fun and unrealistic weaponry make this game fun as hell!
I have an Electric Katana thatb does 2340 damage per swing.
Craft your own weponry.
Such as a flaming shovel.
Electric Sniper
You can also drive boats and Jeeps
As your character levels up so do the zombies! This is so that you arent OP
There are 70 or so levels, Weapons also level up too, and the quests get harder. If you complete harder quests you get more XP and better rewards. The amount of XP also depends on what level you are, which i enjoy. So lets say you're a level 12 or 13 if you complete a normal quest you gain anywhere from 500 to 2500 XP. Where as you're a Level 50 like me you'd be getting around 534,290 XP for that quest.
There are also different classifications, Yellow weapon title font is the best and gray is the worst.
You also gain money in this game, which you use to buy items of all sorts and make repairs to weapons.
I do enjoy this game more than Dead Island"
This is essentialy like a game made by Bethesda. Like "Fallout" or "Skyrim" type game. Only there arent zombies in those games.
I wont spoil anymore of the game for you.
The rest is for you to find out
Good Luck suriving and Have Fun!
25 / 10"

reviewText: Welcome to the tropical Paradise Island known as Palanai. Blue skies, clear waters, beautiful people, Music, culture, drugs alcohol sex, & ZOMBIES! That’s right, More ZOMBIES! You’ll venture thru the Island as you continue your adventure from escaping Banoi as one of the same 4 people that traveled to the Paradise Island looking for work. You will interact with other characters during your travels as you’ll be tasked to help other survivors. This first person ZOMBIE hack&slash, gun&run will keep your heart pounding and raise the hair on the back of your neck. The Story follows a scientist named Serpo whom continues the research in BioWeapons.  This game has few new creatures but, less content than the 1st D I game & is debatable if this is considered a standalone or a high priced expansion. Single player or Co-op, KB&M or Controller with options for mic’s. The graphics are great and the music fits the mood. If you’re a ZOMBIE hunting fan & enjoyed Dead Island as I have then you should not miss out on DIR.

reviewText:
Riptide is a blend of the best ideas from Left4Dead, Dead Rising, Borderlands, and Far Cry. It is set on a beautiful tropical island full of zombie hordes. Now toss in character leveling, skill trees, randomized loot, countless melee weapons, an assortment of firearms, and deadly weapon modifications. It all creates a cohesive, high-quality experience not found anywhere else.

It is critical to understand Riptide is less of a sequel and more of a large expansion pack that delivers part two of the DI story. Being a glorified expansion, Riptide plays virtually identically to DI with a few noticeable improvements. Hence, Riptide is clearly not trying to win over new fans. Rather, it is meant for those who couldn't get enough of the original.

Along with a whole new island named Palanai to explore, Riptide provides a slightly more polished version of DI's core gameplay. There's also a tighter focus on the story and characters with new base defense segments. Guns in general have been greatly improved in Riptide and are now entirely viable. Riptide also features sniper rifles. Using a sniper rifle to expertly splatter a zombie's head like an exploding cantaloupe is as superbly epic as it sounds.

Regarding the island topography, Riptide features beaches, swampy jungles, marinas, bunkers, villages, a big city, and various interiors. Riptide's world is expertly crafted with great attention to detail, always rewarding exploration. A lot of little lore touches help create a feeling of time and place for Palanai. There's also some welcome interface tweaks. The UI is generally classier, with better item comparisons and much improved tabbed inventory management.

Riptide's character system is simply a slightly tweaked version of DI's. Some new skills and weapons add to the fun. A new character focused on Hand-to-Hand is added, Logan, who fits right in and offers some nice back story since he's a local inhabitant.

Riptide features the same auto-scaling system from DI wherein all enemies and loot scale to your level. Also retained is the absolutely brilliant individual level scaling in co-op where a level 10 player can join a level 70 player and each player finds loot and fights enemies at their level.

On the downside, Riptide has the same technical issues and clunky movement from the first game. Fortunately, like the original, there is a free community Helper executable that fixes numerous issues, can change the FOV, can enable SMAA, and removes some annoyances. On the PC side, it is fairly easy to tweak your movement to make it feel as smooth as the best FPS games.

My biggest complaint is just how easy the game is overall. You get a boatload of weapons, components, guns, and ammo. Zombies are very rarely a challenge, and you rarely worry about weapon durability.

Ultimately, Riptide is all about brutally slaughtering zombies. Hacking, smashing, stabbing, electrocuting, burning, decapitating, and crushing are just some methods available. What makes Riptide worth playing is how incredibly responsive the game is to your killing choices. Wonderful spurting and crushing sound effects compliment wonderful visuals of skulls literally exploding. As solid as they are, the story, quests, and events are all just excuses to continue the killing!

Riptide is a power fantasy game inviting you to make your bloody mark on Palanai Island. If you don't enjoy the slaughter I have to question your gamer credentials because this is the pinnacle of zombie murder mayhem.
voteText: 3 of 6 people (50%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
I can’t help but resent how much I enjoyed playing Dead Island Riptide.  Let’s get this out of the way; the game is rough.  Constant graphic problems, horrible bugs, lackluster story and voice acting, illogical gameplay, and some of the most infuriating glitches I have ever experienced are all contained within what is essentially a very long replica of the first game.  That said, as with the first Dead Island, I found myself completed immersed and enjoying the experience in spite of the constant problems.

Game Play – a very, very conflicted 5

Pros:  The fighting mechanics are fun. In fact, they are the primary reason I enjoyed the game. The excessive slashing, stomping, kicking, and weapon throwing is addictive – exactly like it was in the first Dead Island.  Not only are the mechanics the same; the weapons selection and even the upgrade tree don’t seem to have been changed in the slightest.  There are a few new enemies, but for all practical purposes, it’s the same game, which could be a plus if you enjoyed the original.

Cons: However, the frustrating aspects of the first game haven’t been touched.  In fact, the original issues seem to have been compounded.  Thrown weapons still mysteriously disappear with infuriating regularity.  Spawning in the middle of an angry horde seems to happen far too often, and I even experienced completed missions would occasionally restart after a hours of game play later.  At one point 86% of the way through, I had one of the NPCs suddenly refuse to allow me to buy weapons, telling me I hadn’t completed the first mission of the game.  Even the steam integration is poor, regularly resetting my achievement counters on restart. According to my achievements I still haven’t reached 1000 head stomps, in spite of the fact that the in-game stats counter lists over 5000. The list of problems could go on, but this is my internal conflict.  The gameplay is both the salvation and downfall of the game.

Story – 3

Every possible cliché is used, from the evil military, to the evil scientist, to the evil capitalist.  The few parts that are vaguely interesting are usually just recycled plot points from the first Dead Island.  To be fair, the side missions are generally more interesting than the main campaign, but that’s really not saying much.

Mood/Atmosphere – 7

Aside from the fighting mechanics, the other strength of the game is its stylistic flair. The Dead Island world is pretty and appealing, assuming you can actually get the graphics to run properly.  Which leads us to…

Graphics – 6

The inefficient rendering led to constant visual glitches.  At first I thought it might be my slightly dated AMD card, but I’m not alone.  Nvidia and AMD users alike have dozens of support forums trying to troubleshoot the issues, and I found it tragically easier to just turn the settings down instead of trying to isolate whatever the nondescript issue might have been. Some of the issues, like the fact that fire didn’t render half the time, actually affected game play. That said, running around a pretty tropical island is always nice.

Audio Design – 3

Recycling the already repetitive soundtrack of the first Dead Island was lazy, but the fact that many sound effects were missing or just poorly designed was distracting.  Why don’t some items make sounds when dropped?  Why does my character obnoxiously talk out loud to herself during “stealth” missions?  *sigh*

Should I play this?

There’s no way I could actually recommend this to anyone. But if you really enjoyed the first Dead Island, don’t mind the constant glitches, and can somehow get the graphics to work properly, maybe, just maybe, you might enjoy it like I did.

reviewText:
Well lemme just say that this is a pretty awesome game... however that alone doesn't do it justice. Lemme give you gamer hunks some pros and cons and mehhhhs.  Just so you have an idea i played the whole game through by myself and might have a different opinion than some. :D

Pro : the flow of gameplay (smooth virtually no lag)
intensity (i found myself with increased heart-rate when i had a few zombies chasing after me and i needed to climb up a ladder or rocks)
weapons and construct-abilities (finding mods is fun)
quests (the side quests in particular and sometimes long and seemingly pointless. but you level up faster making your gameplay late game quite interesting especially if you are looking out for mods... and more side quests)

Con: some zombie fuctions and movements are.. sketchy.. to say the least (a zombie will run at me and i'll kick it and the one behind it will run right through at times.. a gohst zombie killer..)
the way to boat is, annoying to control especially when you have zombies hopping on (this could be do to me playing by myself.. idk though)

Meh: the continous quest (atlest give me something to aim for, homie wants to pop pain pills i'm straight with that.. but he wants unlimited of them? i think 200 bottles sounds reasonable) i think i'm such a high level because i would travel around the map multiple times and collect all these thinks ang have 126 in my inventory and just level up like a fiend.
kids online (i mean i'm fine with playing with people online.. but .. they ... arn't...)
replay value (lets be honest its not a game you are going to want to repeat the story mode in.. atleast its not as exciting as the first time playing. an addon or extention would be great to include with new contect and quests)

There is some more i could say but all-in-all its a great game. If i could give you some advice. don't die. you lose guap.. stacks on stacks of guap. i think if some features where added it could be a little more fun to play alone but i can't complain.

Happy gaming love bugs

reviewText:
It's hard to find good things about this game but I'll try my best. Here's the game in general:

Pros-Fluid Combat System (This makes up most of the cons, honestly).
-Very fun if played with friends.
-Lots of Weapons to use. Lots of mods to try on your disposal.
-You can choose which main character you want to play. Each with their own special abilities.
-More Special Zombies from the first game.

Neutral-RPG elements (A zombie game with leveling up system. Original but it feels weird)
-Dated Graphics (It's not too bad, Character and Zombie Models look ok, only the Textures look bad)
-Difficulty Spikes (Many people complained about this. It's not really a BIG problem. Most RPG games always have that)

Neutral-Con-Boring Missions, Awesome Rewards
-The Mini-Map will confuse you but the Big Map won't.

Cons-Horrible Options (Go and download Dead Island Riptide Helper, it will fix most graphical and control problems)
-Buying items are better than Looting
-Bad Animations during cutscenes
-Lots of Loading screen
-Boring if played alone
-Story's too short
-Buying stuff will be VERY EXPENSIVE if you reach the ending of the game.

VerdictIt's basically the first Dead Island but with a different map. If you ever had a choice to buy either Dead Island. PICK THE FIRST DEAD ISLAND. This one's more boring.
I still think it's a good CO-OP game. So buy 2 for a friend.

6/10

reviewText: Welcome to the tropical Paradise Island known as Palanai. Blue skies, clear waters, beautiful people, Music, culture, drugs alcohol sex, & ZOMBIES! That’s right, More ZOMBIES! You’ll venture thru the Island as you continue your adventure from escaping Banoi as one of the same 4 people that traveled to the Paradise Island looking for work. You will interact with other characters during your travels as you’ll be tasked to help other survivors. This first person ZOMBIE hack&slash, gun&run will keep your heart pounding and raise the hair on the back of your neck. The Story follows a scientist named Serpo whom continues the research in BioWeapons.  This game has few new creatures but, less content than the 1st D I game & is debatable if this is considered a standalone or a high priced expansion. Single player or Co-op, KB&M or Controller with options for mic’s. The graphics are great and the music fits the mood. If you’re a ZOMBIE hunting fan & enjoyed Dead Island as I have then you should not miss out on DIR.

reviewText:
Riptide is a blend of the best ideas from Left4Dead, Dead Rising, Borderlands, and Far Cry. It is set on a beautiful tropical island full of zombie hordes. Now toss in character leveling, skill trees, randomized loot, countless melee weapons, an assortment of firearms, and deadly weapon modifications. It all creates a cohesive, high-quality experience not found anywhere else.

It is critical to understand Riptide is less of a sequel and more of a large expansion pack that delivers part two of the DI story. Being a glorified expansion, Riptide plays virtually identically to DI with a few noticeable improvements. Hence, Riptide is clearly not trying to win over new fans. Rather, it is meant for those who couldn't get enough of the original.

Along with a whole new island named Palanai to explore, Riptide provides a slightly more polished version of DI's core gameplay. There's also a tighter focus on the story and characters with new base defense segments. Guns in general have been greatly improved in Riptide and are now entirely viable. Riptide also features sniper rifles. Using a sniper rifle to expertly splatter a zombie's head like an exploding cantaloupe is as superbly epic as it sounds.

Regarding the island topography, Riptide features beaches, swampy jungles, marinas, bunkers, villages, a big city, and various interiors. Riptide's world is expertly crafted with great attention to detail, always rewarding exploration. A lot of little lore touches help create a feeling of time and place for Palanai. There's also some welcome interface tweaks. The UI is generally classier, with better item comparisons and much improved tabbed inventory management.

Riptide's character system is simply a slightly tweaked version of DI's. Some new skills and weapons add to the fun. A new character focused on Hand-to-Hand is added, Logan, who fits right in and offers some nice back story since he's a local inhabitant.

Riptide features the same auto-scaling system from DI wherein all enemies and loot scale to your level. Also retained is the absolutely brilliant individual level scaling in co-op where a level 10 player can join a level 70 player and each player finds loot and fights enemies at their level.

On the downside, Riptide has the same technical issues and clunky movement from the first game. Fortunately, like the original, there is a free community Helper executable that fixes numerous issues, can change the FOV, can enable SMAA, and removes some annoyances. On the PC side, it is fairly easy to tweak your movement to make it feel as smooth as the best FPS games.

My biggest complaint is just how easy the game is overall. You get a boatload of weapons, components, guns, and ammo. Zombies are very rarely a challenge, and you rarely worry about weapon durability.

Ultimately, Riptide is all about brutally slaughtering zombies. Hacking, smashing, stabbing, electrocuting, burning, decapitating, and crushing are just some methods available. What makes Riptide worth playing is how incredibly responsive the game is to your killing choices. Wonderful spurting and crushing sound effects compliment wonderful visuals of skulls literally exploding. As solid as they are, the story, quests, and events are all just excuses to continue the killing!

Riptide is a power fantasy game inviting you to make your bloody mark on Palanai Island. If you don't enjoy the slaughter I have to question your gamer credentials because this is the pinnacle of zombie murder mayhem.

reviewText:
I can’t help but resent how much I enjoyed playing Dead Island Riptide.  Let’s get this out of the way; the game is rough.  Constant graphic problems, horrible bugs, lackluster story and voice acting, illogical gameplay, and some of the most infuriating glitches I have ever experienced are all contained within what is essentially a very long replica of the first game.  That said, as with the first Dead Island, I found myself completed immersed and enjoying the experience in spite of the constant problems.

Game Play – a very, very conflicted 5

Pros:  The fighting mechanics are fun. In fact, they are the primary reason I enjoyed the game. The excessive slashing, stomping, kicking, and weapon throwing is addictive – exactly like it was in the first Dead Island.  Not only are the mechanics the same; the weapons selection and even the upgrade tree don’t seem to have been changed in the slightest.  There are a few new enemies, but for all practical purposes, it’s the same game, which could be a plus if you enjoyed the original.

Cons: However, the frustrating aspects of the first game haven’t been touched.  In fact, the original issues seem to have been compounded.  Thrown weapons still mysteriously disappear with infuriating regularity.  Spawning in the middle of an angry horde seems to happen far too often, and I even experienced completed missions would occasionally restart after a hours of game play later.  At one point 86% of the way through, I had one of the NPCs suddenly refuse to allow me to buy weapons, telling me I hadn’t completed the first mission of the game.  Even the steam integration is poor, regularly resetting my achievement counters on restart. According to my achievements I still haven’t reached 1000 head stomps, in spite of the fact that the in-game stats counter lists over 5000. The list of problems could go on, but this is my internal conflict.  The gameplay is both the salvation and downfall of the game.

Story – 3

Every possible cliché is used, from the evil military, to the evil scientist, to the evil capitalist.  The few parts that are vaguely interesting are usually just recycled plot points from the first Dead Island.  To be fair, the side missions are generally more interesting than the main campaign, but that’s really not saying much.

Mood/Atmosphere – 7

Aside from the fighting mechanics, the other strength of the game is its stylistic flair. The Dead Island world is pretty and appealing, assuming you can actually get the graphics to run properly.  Which leads us to…

Graphics – 6

The inefficient rendering led to constant visual glitches.  At first I thought it might be my slightly dated AMD card, but I’m not alone.  Nvidia and AMD users alike have dozens of support forums trying to troubleshoot the issues, and I found it tragically easier to just turn the settings down instead of trying to isolate whatever the nondescript issue might have been. Some of the issues, like the fact that fire didn’t render half the time, actually affected game play. That said, running around a pretty tropical island is always nice.

Audio Design – 3

Recycling the already repetitive soundtrack of the first Dead Island was lazy, but the fact that many sound effects were missing or just poorly designed was distracting.  Why don’t some items make sounds when dropped?  Why does my character obnoxiously talk out loud to herself during “stealth” missions?  *sigh*

Should I play this?

There’s no way I could actually recommend this to anyone. But if you really enjoyed the first Dead Island, don’t mind the constant glitches, and can somehow get the graphics to work properly, maybe, just maybe, you might enjoy it like I did.

reviewText:
Info___
I did NOT play the previous Dead Island game. I've only played in a two player co-op and I wouln't recommend this game for a single player run simply because multiplayer is so much fun.

Pros___
Cool fighting mechanics for close combat like stepping on fallen zombies heads and sending them flying with a kick. Interesting story, fine skill trees (different for each of 5 playable characters) and loads of stuff to do with around 80 side quests, sweet weapon creation and mod ideas, enjoyable defend the base" actions and 4 kind of collectibles that give a better look at game's background story.

Cons___
The game has some minor bugs and few annoyances such as not marking the Dead Zones on the map which you have already finished (Dead Zones are a kind of mini instance
recommended: inability to turn off auto-equip picked up items and inability to select weapons other then using scroll wheel (if I'm wrong on this one
hoursPlayed: please correct me in comments). On rare occasions
voteText:
after dying I respawned far away from my co-op partner. Also some indicator of full rage meter would be quite useful - I used Fury only few times mostly because I kept forgeting it existed.

Summary___
Overall it is very solid zombie slashing co-op game that may serve around 25-30+ hours of gameplay - if zombie killing is what you like then this is a game I STRONGLY recommend."

reviewText:
I know I did'nt play enough yet, but I already found many things in this game that NO ONE MENTION IN ANY REVIEW!

Allow me to break it down.

You got your 4 main survivors from the first Dead Island, and one new character named John who is a soldier of some sort. While selecting your characters, theres a menu that explains their abilities and skills better than the first Dead Island! After selecting your character, you have a small selection of build styles of some sort, for example you can choose to be built for combat which gives you a reasonable head start on some combat skills, or be built for survival which gives an early start for your loot and inventory and durability skills, etc.

There is better interaction and interacting menus than the first Dead Island in my opinion. Theres also friendly AI that actually aid you in combat and even have their own weapons and can fight for themselves! You get equiped with a fire arm really early at the near start of the game but don't keep it afterwards.

Ofcourse theres side quests and fetch quests which can be a pain sometimes (or all the time) but I find a couple enjoyable so far.

The only reason I got this game was to continue from the first Dead Island because I liked it. Sound is still good, graphics still okay but I'm playing at Ultra which looks really great.

So if still on sale and you want to try it go for it, you also got the refund thing if you don't like it, so good luck and have fun!

reviewText:
More of Dead Island so if you liked that then get this. However just like that game it is not a great game engine and does not perform too great. It has stutters and jerks but not constant stuttering so I was able to play through the game without major bother. The engine still sucks though and their newer engine they used for Dying Light is much, much better. This game also has many more small technical issues than DI1, such as sound glitches and general gameplay glitches.

A step down from DI, stick with the original unless you loved it so much you have to have more, because this is the exact same game just with more glitches now.

6.5/10

reviewText:
If you're buying this, you likely remember the first game, and you know exactly what you're getting into. For those people: this game isn't too different from the first one. Comparatively, I'd say this one plays somewhat better, but the plot is still just as cringeworthy (as is the facial animation). Still, like the first one, the gameplay is pretty damn fun (the new character can constantly do a running kick that sends people flying), and cooperative play is guarenteed to have some good times.

If you don't remember the first game: don't buy this game expecting a serious take on the zombie apocalypse. Deep Silver has not been able to cash in on their promise of storytelling, as the games are notorious for awkward animation, terribly predictable and uninteresting plot, and utterly one dimensional characters.

HOWEVER, they are also a great deal of fun, and are great games to play with friends.

reviewText:
Riptide is very similar to the original Dead Island, and pretty much just a continuation of the story.  In fact you can just import your character from the first game into Riptide and level it to 70 now.  There are some very minor changes to gameplay but nothing really notable.

There isn't as much content as in the first game in regards to quests and areas.  I played both games in entirety with only a single character.  In the first game I was able to waste about 100 hours doing everything; in Riptide it only took me 60 hours.

I do suggest you play Riptide if you are interested at all in the simple story, as it is a true continuation picking up right where the first game leaves off.  If you played the original game just for zombie killing and the story means nothing to you then you will likely get nothing extra from this game.

Highly enjoyable game, I recommend anyone who hasn't played Dead Island and Riptide pick them up and give them a try.  Dead Island 2 is right around the corner, and I can't wait for that too!

reviewText:
More of the same from the first game, but with a few new features.
A new character is added, a guy that is good with his fists. If you play as him, expect to be using just hand to hand weapons.
A new base defense mechanic, where you have to protect yourself and the NPCs from waves of zombies.
A few new boss enemies, including a lady zombie that likes to scream at you.
This time to get to drive a boat too, even though it can get annoying quite quickly.
Overall, it just feels like a DLC expansion, instead of a sequel.

What the most important thing is that there are new weapons and new mods. Expect even more crazy designs for weapons.

Remember, you are here to kill zombies. Kill those zombies.

Don't forget to bring a friend.

reviewText: So I had the first Dead Island on console and loved it in all honesty. It was a mess, it was riddled with bugs, so on and so forth, but it was fun and delightful and even challenging, at least as a new player. Playing DI:R honestly feels the same, but it still holds that fun, broken and enjoyable zombie head bashing rompiness feel that makes the game a great time. I've already noticed (at 1.7 hours gameplay) that Riptide is noticably more challenging, providing slightly tougher gameplay and harder hitting enemies and this alone helps the game rise from it's broken abyss. The atmosphere, at least in my opinion, is also a bit eerier which I love. It doesn't feel so much like a 'vacation gone wrong' like the first game and instead puts a darker feel on things and makes it spoopi- er, spookier.\nDefinitely play it with friends and have many a shenanigan.

reviewText:
Main reason for giving a negative review for this game is that so far it feels much worse than the first part. It's still alright game especially if you can get it for cheap on a sale.

I've now played 3 hours and I have almost zero sense of storyline. Every place has 10 times more zombies than in the first Dead Island game. After you kill the zombies you're safe in only a very limited zone as the zombies respawn very quickly after you move ahead a bit. Basicially this turns the game much more Hack 'n' Slash than the first one and this makes the storyline feel much thinner than in the first one. Also due to this Hack 'n' Slash system they've added a stupid achievement system that pops up on the screen about 10 times more frequently than in the first game.

Perhaps I'll start liking it more down the road but right now I can't stand playing for much longer than 30mins at a time because there's too much combat as the zombies basicially keep coming all the time. If you wanna Hack 'n' Slash zombies, Left 4 Dead 2 is much better game for that.

reviewText:
Dead Island Riptide is the sequel to Dead Island. But will you want to play it ?

Dead Island Riptide pickups as soon as Dead Island ends. We are transported on a boat where the scientist want to do the experiments on the immune survivors to find a cure for the zombie virus. But it turns out the boat is full of the undead and it crashes on the island of Palanai and it's up to you to find a way off the island.

Gameplay wise the game is the same as the previous title. The game is a hack and slash RPG where you can loot chests for better weapons and find blueprints to craft even better items. There's also guns but you really want to use melee weapons as the fire power is pretty much useless.

Graphics are identical to the first game as well. There are minor changes like the better water effects and a few texture upgrades. There's also this funny effect where the weather changes instantly and it looks horrible.

Audio in this game is beyond horrible. The soundtrack is alright for the most part, but everything else is just awful. Many times the audio would cut out and wouldn't return unless I rebooted the game. There's a lot of horrible sound effects like zombie puking noises and some of the weapon sounds which are terrible.

The game is pretty difficult. I played with three people from start to finish and the game scaled the enemy level to the highest player in the lobby which is really awful. Some zombies do more damage than others and the difficulty comes in the bullet sponge bosses, who move too slow and take up too much damage.

Level Design is a mess to say the least. The first game wasn't a problem to navigate around, but this just takes it to a whole new level. The map doesn't even look like the game layout making some of the travels to the objectives or secret bosses a pain in the ♥♥♥. It took some time to find what were looking for just because the map design is horrible.

Game is really long. It took me 15 hours to finish the entire game and finish all side quests and all of the dead zones. There's not much replay value unless you want try playing with the different characters, but overall there's not much replay value here.

The game is a buggy mess. The sound bugs was one thing, but there are a few problems I would love to point out. The game has physics problems. I once had to jump over an obstacle, but the game flew me into the air instead. Some of the dead zone bosses appeared after we already killed them, just to name a few bugs.

Dead Island Riptide is a very poor sequel. It's boring, the story is awful, a lot of bugs, connection problems with co-op. I really wanted to like this game, but in the end all I can say are bad things. Only check this game out on sale, don't even bother at full price or check out the first Dead Island which was in general a better game. I give Dead Island Riptide a 4.5/10

reviewText:
Quick Review

Dead Island: Riptide comes across as just another means of cashing in on the Dead Island franchise with very little effort in designing new weapons, areas, enemies, and characters. While it is true that Riptide feels like a stand alone expansion to its predecessor, it accomplishes so much more.

More workbenches allow for less backtracking. You are able to repair, upgrade, and mod your weapons more often thanks to the larger abundance of workbenches within the game world. The starting level is increased to 15 to allow for players to jump right into the game, becoming zombie killing machines right off the bat.

Storywise, Riptide doesn't really accomplish anything special or memorable, but it does deliver a much better performance than the first. The story focuses more on the survivors of the first game, giving them an actual story rather than just leaving them as blank slates. This helps to create a smooth often laughable B Zombie narrative.

The combat hasn't changed much from the first, but thanks to the starting level increase, it makes the game feel more consistent. The first Dead Island didn't understand if it wanted to be a survival or action game, where as Riptide is an action zombie massacre game through and through.

Overall, Riptide is actually a pretty damn good zombie game. Highly reccommended if you're looking for a zombie game or just a nice co-op game. 8/10

reviewText:
I played Riptide before playing Dead Island, and in all honestly I shouldn't have bothered with DI, since I found Riptide overall more enjoyable. But I got DI along with the Riptide pre-purchase iirc.

I'm just going to keep it simple, the game is OK at best. The highlights are the nice environments you can explore and fight in. The killing zombies part, which while incredibly repetitive (to be expected), is fun. The variety of weapons you can use to chop and blast them is great.

The bad points are similair to the first game Dead Island. Cheesy dialogue and poor storyline make it uninteresting and tedious at times to play through. You can just run around like a lunatic and hack and slash away with no real consequence. Dying to a zombie isn't punishing.

I must say, in general, DI: Riptide is superior to Dead Island, so if you want to play this game, stick to Riptide. Don't expect much out of this game though, other than running around killing things in paradise, it doesn't offer too much. IIRC the zombies might be a bit harder than the one's in Dead Island. However I still wouldn't recommend the game, 5/10 at best.

reviewText:
I played Riptide before playing Dead Island, and in all honestly I shouldn't have bothered with DI, since I found Riptide overall more enjoyable. But I got DI along with the Riptide pre-purchase iirc.

I'm just going to keep it simple, the game is OK at best. The highlights are the nice environments you can explore and fight in. The killing zombies part, which while incredibly repetitive (to be expected), is fun. The variety of weapons you can use to chop and blast them is great.

The bad points are similair to the first game Dead Island. Cheesy dialogue and poor storyline make it uninteresting and tedious at times to play through. You can just run around like a lunatic and hack and slash away with no real consequence. Dying to a zombie isn't punishing.

I must say, in general, DI: Riptide is superior to Dead Island, so if you want to play this game, stick to Riptide. Don't expect much out of this game though, other than running around killing things in paradise, it doesn't offer too much. IIRC the zombies might be a bit harder than the one's in Dead Island. However I still wouldn't recommend the game, 5/10 at best.

reviewText:
This game has the worst save system I've ever experienced in all games I've played. The devs thought they knew how to design a fully effed-up automatic save system, yeah they are right.

There is no way to save your game progress if you decided to stop between check points, mybe you are tired, or maybe you need to go to work, etc. You will lose some minor progress if you force quit, maybe some mod materials or cash, usually it's no big deal.

However if the game crashed, like in my scenario: I thrown my weapons to take out a Floater, then picked the weapons up, then the game CTD'ed. I restart the game, not just I've been kicked back 1000 miles away (since the devs decided check points should be 1000 miles apart), all the thrown and retrieved weapons are gone! All gone! Among them is my best orange weapon. I'm totally bummed and lost my interest to play on.

There is no way to load an older save so that I can at least get back my orange weapon. In fact, there is no older saves at all, the game keeps one and only one save slot for one character, and the bl00dy auto save just overwritten all my hope of getting back my best and most powerful weapon. Good job, stupid game developers.

If Dead Island 2 also features" such stupid save system

reviewText:
Somewhat recommended. I can't say that game is really good. TL;DR: Some bugs and goofs, mediocre story, average quests. Please note this game has extreme blood and gore and there isn't any option/mod to turn this off.

The game continues from first Dead Island and there is plot summary about what happened before. There is a new place and a new extra character.

Since i didn't play the first one, i can't compare. As i see, Dead Island inspired from many games. As island concept and vehicles, reminded me Far Cry 2 and 3. Crafting something reminded me Dead Rising 2 but you have to find/buy blueprints instead of unlocking combo cards. Repairing something for money is so silly but it's a game in the end. Chrome Engine 5 is weird, its between current-gen and old style graphics. Especially blood-stain effect on weapons and raindrop effect made me feel like i'm playing a game from 2003. I can't say Techland didn't put an effort to develop DI as good as possible but something isn't right as well. If i can see that dullness, i'll edit this recommendation.


Let's take a look for pros and cons:
+ Open world
+ Crafting
+ Seems boring but somehow it make you keep it play

- Vehicles are generally useless
- Quickly respawning zombies
- Some weird bugs (i.e. sometimes you stuck somewhere in the water and can be drowned)
- Silly underwater and getting-wet-by-waterfall screen effects
- Looting is painful and after a while getting boring
- Inventory menu could be more useful
- (imho) Too much blood and gore and it can't be turned off

If you want to try this one, i can recommend to wait for a great discount. Not worth for the full price.

reviewText:
Considering Dead Island had its fair share of bugs and other issues, I kind of expected the sequel (or what ever you want to call it) to be a bit more polished and - well - less buggy.

But man, was I wrong. Somehow they managed to make Riptide even more buggier and unbalanced. Finding good weapons is easy considering most of them seem to respawn instantly within 2 seconds of picking it up, meaning you can fill your inventory with a handful of katanas with varying damage and just pick the best one and sell the rest. This of course leads to having endless piles of money as well which you can again use to purchase the most rarest weapons just like that. This instantly ruins the fun for me considering theres real no sense of discovery for good weapons, or challenge when it comes to killing zombies. And as if having superior weapons and ridiculous abilities like insta-kill stomping isnt enough, your Rage abilities can take care of a horde in an instant with no effort what so ever.

So if the gameplay itself is so boring for the reasons mentioned above, maybe the story or quests have something to offer? Well, as you should know from playing the original Dead Island, the overall story and cutscenes are more embarrassing to watch than anything else. What comes to the side quests, its pretty much Can you bring me my astma inhaler" and then you run around the city killing the same bunch of zombies and collecting the same respawned weapons you picked up last time.

The only positive thing I can say about this game
date: is that chopping off limbs from the zombies one by one is pretty satisfying and fun to do in the beginning
recommended: but since its so easy to kill the zombies in a single hit after a few level ups this doesnt carry the game very far... The only reason I played it for this many hours is because a friend of mine felt like he needed to complete the game to get something for the money spent on it
hoursPlayed: and he didnt want to play it alone (even punching yourself in the face is more fun if a friend is there watching).\n\nSo all in all
voteText: if you want challenge and/or good story

reviewText:
This Game is positively awful.

I played quite a bit of this game and I have come up against multiple problem with it.

This game ran very poorly even though I have a somewhat good pc and every time you look at water the frames drop dramatically which I wouldn't mind, but the water is literally everywhere.

This also brings me on to another problem with the game which is the area. The main part of the area is that the place is covered in water which forces you to us boats which are the most horrible thing to control. The other problem with the area is that not a single part of it is interesting, it lacked character.

Yet another problem I had with the game is that the combat in the game is the dullest most boring thing ever. Every time you try to hit an enemy it uses stamina which make the combat a mixture trying to hit and walk away.

Overall I definitely recommend you stay away from this game completely
