reviewText:
Oh, well! A Dead Island sequel that could have easily been just a DLC or labelled as an expansion pack. Money-wise I purchased it for a relatively cheap price so I have no issues with this. It's just that the game does not really offer anything new. There are some cool new weapons, some new monsters and the 4-member team now gets a 5th member.

The story takes place immediately after the 1st game as our protagonists get apprehended by the military. Their ship gets attacked by zombies (I guess someone gets infected and all hell breaks loose) so during the first level you need to escape the ship. Our survivors then find themselves on Palanai - another island that got the virus so now we are back in action for a 2nd time.

Some cool new things you have in the sequel":

-weather system that changes in accordance with the action: as the combat becomes more intense so does the weather
-we now have rowboats: this is an interesting addition as along with this a new zombie type has been introduced that can actually survive in the water and cannot drown
-coop gameplay is much better: I did not experience any disconnections (played the game on its release date) and when playing with someone there's a new auto-balancing system instead of the limitations in the first game
-we can import our characters from the previous game as they are in the sequel with basically the same skill tree: they can start at level 15 now
-there are some new weapons such as the various grenade types and we also have sniper rifle and rocket launcher at our disposal
-there are sequences where the aim is to protect an area while the zombie are swarming at you - you can put up fences and place mines - these parts are really cool and are for the coop experience

Overall
date: Riptide is a good game. There are some cool new feature and many of the bugs / glitches of the original game were corrected. Also
recommended: it should be noted that Techland's Chrome 5 engine runs superbly and graphically the game can be beautiful at times. It's not a Crysis 2 but it gets its job done properly.\n\nI recommend this game to the fans of the original only and I believe its Steam pricing is a bit high so perhaps you should pick this one up when it's on sale."

reviewText:
honestly, i dont know why dead island riptide has alot of negative reviews. Dead island riptide is in my opinion one of my favorite games. but i do agree that it feels more like an expansion because it is pretty much the same as the original dead island, but features a few new things like having a group and surviving together, and upgrading them to have the perfect ideal group, and not to mention the stunning graphics dead island riptide has to offer. I also love the new weapon modifications as well as the whole plot of how the virus started.

Pros:
-Amazing graphics
-Great story
-one of the best zombie killing games to just walk around and freely kill as many zombies as you want (besides dead rising of course)
-fun coop to mess around with friends
-overall great

Cons:
-feels more like a dead island expansion pack
-alot of bugs for combat and walking
-Glitchy (to reduce glitching go to options, and fix the resolution to a setting called best preformance")

overall Dead island riptide is a great game and i reccomend it to any gamer who wants a free roam zombie killing game.

Score: 9.1/10

reviewText:
tl;dr: Want Co-op? AVOID LIKE THE PLAGUE


If you plan on playing this for Co-op (IMO, the best and ONLY way to play a DI game) do NOT purchase this. I'm running an i7 3770 with a non-ref 290x (latest drivers at this time), and experience crashes within minutes of inviting or joining games.

I've covered the recommended solutions from the forums, and the crash logs are absolutely jammed with extraneous information which helps troubleshooting in no way at all.

I loved the first DI, it was a great Co-op experience, and the analog fighting controls are just plain awesome. But I never had this many issues with it. Ridiculous doens't even begin to describe it.

reviewText: It's not impressive, and the storyline is mostly rehashed from the original.  Another reviewer compared it to DLC, and this is basically true.  It plays out like a side quest (albeit a long one) from the first game.  The new character, John, plays a good bit like Sam B.  You're able to import an existing character from the first game, and new characters begin at level 15.  Beware of playing at low detail levels, as I did, because you won't be able to see environmental hazards like fire AT ALL.  While this has a bit more polish than an indie game, it certainly doesn't feel like a AAA title.  I'd give it a 6/10.

reviewText:
Do enjoy fun, in-depth storyline?
Do you enjoy good looking cutscenes?
Do you enjoy good voice acting?
Do you enjoy good level desine?
If so, do not buy this game.
Half the levels just feel like a maze to make it seem like there is more content. The storyline is one of the worst I have ever seen and simply makes no sense at all. All levels are repetative. The good thing I can say about this game is the weapon system. I enjoyed playing with the modifications on the firearms in particular (whichj you don't get until 3/4 of the way through the game).
To sum up: ridiculous storyline, bad level design, annoying repetative missions, but you can watch zombies heads become tiny gilblets with a variety of different weapons if you play for about 10 hours first.

reviewText: It's not impressive, and the storyline is mostly rehashed from the original.  Another reviewer compared it to DLC, and this is basically true.  It plays out like a side quest (albeit a long one) from the first game.  The new character, John, plays a good bit like Sam B.  You're able to import an existing character from the first game, and new characters begin at level 15.  Beware of playing at low detail levels, as I did, because you won't be able to see environmental hazards like fire AT ALL.  While this has a bit more polish than an indie game, it certainly doesn't feel like a AAA title.  I'd give it a 6/10.

reviewText:
The question that most people would ask... Is this a good game?  No.  It isn't a good game.  It's a terrible game, with poor controls, crappy weapons that hurt you more than they hurt who you are fighting, and an abysmal ending.

Fans of the first game may fine some level of enjoyment in this, but the only real enjoyment I had was playing co-op with friends.  Be warned, if you even think of modding your weapons to apply fire, poison, or shock, your friends will get mad at you as they take damage from your attacks.  By the end, I gave up on most melee weapons and just used guns almost full time.

If you find this on sale, great, you might have fun.  Otherwise, stay away unless you are extremely devoted to the series.

reviewText:
As someone who got this in a $4 bundle from the Deep Silver 2 Humble Bundle, I still feel that I've wasted my money.

Here's why:
-90% of the first few chapters' gameplay is just fetchquests. For something of a triple-A title, you'd think gameplay would be less generic.
-It's full of bland, unoriginal characters.
-None of the gameplay is any different than Dead Island (save for a few quality of life improvements, like removing one of the head-stomp animations.)
-You'll be running around a lot, so expect having to mod in a stamina extender.

At best, this game should have been a $10 DLC for Dead Island. Being a stand-alone title, this is just rediculous.

reviewText:
Not much to say.  This is like a giant DLC for the original Dead island.  Many recycled Zombies, animations, weapons, textures, items, ect ect.  It is a continuation of the story and fewer bugs than the original.  While the game is shorter than the original, the amount of time to beat it is about the same if you include side quests.

However the original is a lot bigger in terms of areas, places to see, and textures.  I still love the melee combat and smashing zombies is good fun.

The gun play is ok, but there is almost no people to shoot back at you with the exception of a few rare areas.  This game also feels much more easy.

Anyway - cool gameplay, fun melee, boring guns, and loads of zombies.  I totally had  a blast for 20 hours, but I hated the way it ended and I think the original was better imo.

reviewText:
Dead Island Riptide (LOL Rest in peace tide) carries directly after the first Dead Island, as a direct result everything about this game is idenical to the last game.

The Graphics back when Dead island first came out was very good, now..Its still got it, it can look stunning, even the rain has nice drop effects..However it can be a bit of a pig on the system resorces.

Sound, voice acting I think is fine for the most part, but the toons don't really seem to sound to the situation they was in..The first one also had this.. The music is quiet mostly till you makecontact with zombies or you go in a not very nice place...It is more then capable of makin your heart pump is pretty much what I mean.
The Zombies sound terrifying partically the stronger onces, for some reason through with all the ambaince and the music it really is hard to define were the little buggers are or if it was just the music.

Gameplay, plays idenically to DeadIsland, but it plays a bit more like a RPG then before..As you may now upgrade your group that will fight along side you when they are under attack..Other then this not much has really changed everything about it is simlier to the last, they have added new weapons to kill the zombies in ever more ...interessting and bloody ways..There is a few new skills and moves for each toon also, plus a new toon,

Dead Island is abit like marmite, not alot of people like it, I really don't see why its a fun, tense can be terrifying game and now its even harder..alone and more of a challange..But when you got a game that can put alot of pressure on you its not fun, and the targetting system( althroigh its very good) can troll you hard, making it hard to hit fast Zombies, but when you hit with a rare lighting modded meat smasher malet and kill them one kill it is SOO satifying, or boot them down stairs and what them come apart in a bloody mess its.....AWSOME

reviewText: Atmospheric, gorgeous, and intense, though not without the quirk or two, Dead Island Riptide does what the first game did very well, but better, while optimizing and streamlining the overall game experience.\n\nPlotwise, DIR Doesn't really do much outside of your typical Escape the zombies and find out all this conspiracy ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t" tropes. The game prefers to tell stories through the environments you visit and the people you help out. The island of Panai is less "touristy" than the first game
date: which lends its areas a sense of ruggedness and hostility. Whether you're winding through the claustrophobic streets of Henington (?) or wading through the monsoons in the jungle
recommended: DIR presents you with some of the most gorgeous visuals this generation and the right balance of horror and terror. Environments are well-detailed
hoursPlayed: with tons of places to explore and nooks and crannies to turn over. It's just a shame the characters don't share the same level of care
voteText: with most of them looking uncanny valley-worthy
helpfulPercent: if not downright hideous.\n\nCombat
votesHelpful: another Dead Island staple
votesTotal: has been improved and better fleshed out than in the first game. The  RPG elements have been refined
votesFunny: with a few new skills and the ability to further refine and individualize your character with weapon skill levels. Use a lot of blades and you'll get better with them. Shoot a lot of enemies and your firearms skill will increase. It's much deeper than the hollow RPG elements in the original game
commentsCount: which were limited to XP and perks.\n\nEnemy AI is considerably better
column16: although you fight considerably less human enemies this time around. Shooting is vastly improved to the point where it's actually fun and preferable to kill with bullets as opposed to blades. No longer will you feel bad for rolling as the firearms expert
column17: although there's still no reason to play with the unarmed or throwing skills. Areas scattered around the game called "Dead Zones" offer challenging nests of monsters to clean out for sweet loot. Additionally hub defense missions are just the right amount of frantic
column18: although your allies could do a better job taking out the zombies.\n\nDIR plays with fear just as well as the first game. Even as a seasoned veteran of its predecessor
column19: DIR still manages to move you with equal parts horror and terror. Infected sprint at you and make your trek accross the island much scarier if you intend to traverse without combat
column20: and slow-shambling zombies crowd you and stop at nothing to sink their teeth into you. The special infected are back
column21: from Rams to Floaters to Suiciders
column22: accompanied by the Wrestler and Screamer
column23: among others. They are welcome additions to the cast of hostiles
column24: though they tend to show up way too often in the game's closing chapters.\n\nSpeaking of which
column25: the game's pacing in general just feels weird. You'll most likely forget *why* you're doing the things you do
column26: and your accomplices will relocate from base to base in a giant pilgrimage. It's a nice feeling
column27: but like the first game you don't seem to care about the one-dimensional protagonists and the plot starts to fall apart. The game's closure is rather unsatisfying
column28: to top it all off. Thankfully
column29: the story isn't a major player in this game
column30: and I'm glad Techland chose to fix up the game than try to provide a stellar plot. Obscure bugs and glitches still happen
column31: but they're cosmetic for the most part
column32: and nothing breaks your quests or your stats. It's just too bad the cars in the game still handle like cardboard boxes on stone wheels. Overall
column34: DIR feels like a finished product
column35: whereas the original Dead Island felt like a late-stage beta.\n\nDead Island Riptide gives you more of the combat-heavy open-world goodness you crave at the expense of a rather mediocre plot and some odd cosmetic bugs. If you want an immersive
column36: beautiful open-world experience or just want a satisfying limb dismemberment simulator
column37: then DIR is a good fit for you. If you hated Dead Island
column38: or if you want something other than your standard "zombie virus" plot
column39: then this game will disappoint you."

reviewText:
Having bought DI1, DI:R and DI:E in one bundle - I decided to sit my butt down and play through them back to back, starting with good old DI which I had completed back in 2011. This allowed me to flow from DI and DI:R and review it fresh from memory - And make a proper comparison. It also allowed me to play both of the games 'up to date' version, whereas a lot of 'old' reviews complained of 'bugs' that do not exist anymore, thankfully.

That is the first thing - While the game has it flaws, just like DI did - The later version has absolutely no 'blockers'. Not once did the game crash, become unplayable, or put any unintentional issue in my way to stop me playing. Gameplay was smooth, with one single instance of minor FPS drop in one specific area (while using FRAPS) on my beastly computer - And even then, it was for a barely noticeable amount of time.

Story wise - Well, nobody plays DI for the story... After all, there's only so much most games can do when dealing with zombie apocalypses - And so it centers on the characters. All previous characters, and sub-characters (temporarily) appear - So you can go from DI to DI:R, import your favourite characters progress and dive right back into kicking some ♥♥♥. What is worth noting is that the developers finally understood that having a 100% playable roster that is barely likeable is a bad thing - And so, they've altered stories and interactions to make the characters even just that TINY bit more likeable, which is a good thing. Even the sub-characters who tag along might leave a small impression on you.

Combat is same old same old. Yes, there are some minor tweaks here and there, as well as a few new additions, which means it is 'slightly' improved from DI - But overall it's pretty much the same - Which some would love, while others will hate. If you enjoyed crafting your own gear and then playing 'how many bones can I break before I kill this walker' then you won't be disappointed. There are now more variations of familiar zombies, as well as a slightly increase beastiary (new enemies) - And a feature I loved was adding little grindable instances all around the map which contain not only valuable items and quest items, but sub-bosses with their own minor stories, even if they are simple souped up versions of existing monsters.

The 'team quests' and 'base defense' idea was nice though thankfully not overdone - As the base defending is predictable and samey, though it does add more zombie carnage, which is never bad. Singleplayers will get to enjoy watching the other cast-members loitering around and passing comments on the current situation, which gives them more 'presence' compared to DI1, where they only appeared in cut-scenes, or multiplayer.

One major improvement is the fact that flares and flashlight are now relevant. Some areas are almost completely pitch-black and force you to conserve battery power, bring flaming weapons, or toss flares around just so you can see if there's a walker waiting around that corner who wants to nibble your giblets. This sadly only partially ups the tension (I wont say 'scares' as it's still not scary) but it's a very welcome change.

The locations are gorgeous and far improved on DI1, with some great set-pieces and good pacing which breaks the two maps up between flooded jungles, creepy tunnels, zombie infested bungalows full of bosses, city-scape, wooden villages and laboratories. Even if the game at times may look like DI, that look doesn't stay long - And Riptide feels completely unique to it.

Unfortunately, just like DI, the game falls flat by the climax - With an uninteresting boss and a silly 'mutation' twist on the story - And the ending, which is open to interpretation, seems to have annoyed more than it did satisfy - Though with DI2 on the horizon, we can only hope loose ends are tied up in the new game.

Overall - I am extremely happy to have purchased Riptide - And to have played it with far less bugs than what were reported with before.

Ultimately - If you really liked DI1 and can stomach more of the same - Then Riptide is essentially DI1.5 - A nicer looking and improved version of the game you either loved or hated.

Me? I loved it. Thumbs up!

reviewText:
Picking up immediately where the original left off, Dead Island: Riptide changes very little from the first installment. The characters are the same with only one new addition to the group, the gameplay is identical and the environment isn't very exciting. That being said, the game still provides hours of endless zombie maiming fun and if you liked the first game, you'll like Riptide.

Pros:
- Huge range of weapons including more guns!!
- Zombie killing is still as fun as ever
- The game runs and looks beautiful

Cons:
- Nothing new from the original
- Lack of characters
- Best enjoyed in co-op

reviewText:
[WARNING: This review will be based off of my opinion, you have been warned.]
First off, I wanna say that this game is amazing! I had a lot of fun playing through the entire game. There were a few bugs here and there, but overall, very fun!

Pros
-Very fun
-Has a nice feel to it
-Ok story
-Good world
-Good weapon physics (upgrading and repairing)
-Funny character lines
-Fun weapons
-Leaves off after Dead Island

Cons
-Slightly buggy
-Enemies can sometimes be overpowered
-Sometimes frustrating
-Hard to find some crafting parts (looking at you metal scrap)

Overall: Best $6.74 I've ever spent
Rating: 9.5/10
Price range: $5 - $15
